cariyāpiṭakapāḷi.meaning_2: the Pāḷi text of the Cariyāpiṭaka; canonical text of the Book of Conduct
cariyāpiṭakapāḷi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound referring to the canonical Pāḷi text of the Cariyāpiṭaka, the 13th book of the Khuddaka Nikāya, which details the Buddha's past conducts as a bodhisatta. The term uses 'pāḷi' in the sense of the scriptural language or text itself.

akittivaggo.meaning_2: Chapter on Disrepute; Section on Infamy
akittivaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of the first chapter in the Pārājika section of the Vinaya Piṭaka, focusing on themes of infamy and disrepute arising from monastic offenses. 'Akitti' denotes the opposite of fame, implying disgrace, while 'vagga' indicates a chapter or section.

akitticariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound formed from akitti (infamy, privative of kitti 'fame') and cariyā (conduct), indicating conduct that brings or is associated with infamy or disgrace.

bodhipācanaṃ.meaning_2: that which ripens in awakening; cause leading to enlightenment
bodhipācanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sabbaṃ taṃ bodhipācanaṃ', the compound refers to all things that mature or come to fruition in the state of bodhi (awakening), metaphorically suggesting karmic or causal factors that drive one toward enlightenment, akin to a goad urging spiritual progress.

atītakappe.meaning_2: in the past aeon; in a bygone age
atītakappe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'atītakappe caritaṃ', the locative form 'atītakappe' indicates the context or time of the conduct being set aside, meaning 'in the past aeon' or 'in a bygone era'. Here, 'atīta' means 'past' and 'kappa' refers to 'aeon' or 'age', forming a compound used in a temporal locative sense.

pavakkhissaṃ.meaning_2: in (the matter of) explaining; in the explanation
pavakkhissaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pavakkhissaṃ is a locative singular of an irregular future stem pavakkha derived from pavacati (to explain), used adverbially to mean 'in this explanation' or 'regarding what I will explain'. In the sentence 'pavakkhissaṃ suṇohi me', it sets the context for the ensuing explanation, with 'in this eon' likely a mistranslation of the adverbial use.

vipinakānane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vipinakānane is the locative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound vipinakānana, used in the context of entering 'into the formidable jungle', where vipina implies a dense or wild forest and kānana adds the sense of a wooded glade, together evoking a fearsome wilderness.

tapatejena.meaning_2: fires of mortification; burning heat of ascetic practice
tapatejena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the sentence to indicate being burned by the intense heat arising from ascetic mortification, metaphorically representing the suffering of extreme self-denial.
tapatejena.translation_1: Then, burned by the fires of my mortification,

tidivābhibhū.meaning_2: sovereign of the third heaven; lord of the Tāvatiṃsa heaven
tidivābhibhū.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, 'tidivābhibhū' refers to Sakka, the ruler of the Tāvatiṃsa heaven (the heaven of the Thirty-three gods), described as heated or fervent (santatto), likely in a narrative of divine action or appearance.
tidivābhibhū.translation_1: the sovereign of the heaven of the Thirty-three,

sakaṭāhena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sakaṭāhena ākiriṃ', the instrumental form indicates the pot into which the action of placing (ākiriṃ) occurs, matching the English 'in his pot'. The compound suggests a specific type of pot, perhaps a 'cart-pot' or specialized vessel, though kaṭāha alone means pot.
sakaṭāhena.translation_1: I placed them in his pot.

datvānahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form datvānahaṃ is a combination of the absolutive datvā 'having given' and the pronoun ahaṃ 'I', functioning as a single unit in the sentence to indicate the speaker's action of giving followed by self-reference. In the context, it translates to 'After giving him the leaves, I...' where the giving is directed to 'him' (tassa).

nikkujjitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'nikkujjitvāna bhājanaṃ' means 'having turned over the plate', indicating the action of inverting or flipping the plate, likely in a monastic rule scenario from the Vinaya.

punesanaṃ.meaning_2: seeking again; repeated search; longing for more
punesanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'punesanaṃ jahitvāna' refers to abandoning the repeated seeking or quest for additional food, indicating a cessation of foraging or desire for more sustenance.
punesanaṃ.translation_1: and having given up on seeking more food,

jahitvāna.meaning_2: to give up; to abandon; to relinquish
jahitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence, 'jahitvāna' functions as an absolutive form indicating the action of giving up seeking more food, parallel to the English translation 'having given up on seeking more food'. The variant spelling with 'tvāna' may reflect metrical or dialectal usage, equivalent to standard 'jahitvā'.
jahitvāna.translation_1: and having given up on seeking more food,

mamantikaṃ.meaning_2: near me; to me; close to me
mamantikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form mamantikaṃ is a locative singular of the compound mama + antika, used idiomatically in Pāḷi to denote proximity or approach 'to me'. The sentences illustrate this as 'he came to me' or 'he drew close to me', aligning with the locative case's function of indicating place or goal of motion.

anolaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'anolaggo' describes a state of mental non-attachment or non-clinging, paralleling 'ungrasping' in the English translation, often used in meditative or ethical contexts to indicate freedom from grasping at sensory objects or concepts.

evamevamadāsahaṃ.meaning_2: just so; in just the same way; similarly
evamevamadāsahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form evamevamadāsahaṃ appears to be a scribal error or non-standard variant; the standard Pāḷi reading is evamevam adāsaṃ haṃ, where evameva functions as an adverb meaning 'in just the same way,' emphasizing similarity in the act of giving as per the English translation. The additional 'madāsa' does not correspond to standard entries and may be a misreading of 'm eva adāsaṃ' or similar.
evamevamadāsahaṃ.translation_1: I gave in just the same way.

vivaṇṇiyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sarīrasmiṃ vivaṇṇiyaṃ', the locative 'sarīrasmiṃ' (in the body) combined with 'vivaṇṇiyaṃ' (neuter nominative/accusative) functions as a predicate, negated by the context to mean 'my body is not discolored', emphasizing the body's pristine or healthy state.

dānamuttamaṃ.meaning_2: supreme gift; highest offering; ultimate charity
dānamuttamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'dadeyyaṃ dānamuttamaṃ', the compound refers to the supreme or highest form of giving, likely the Dhamma or ultimate charity in Buddhist teachings, as an accusative object of the optative verb 'dadeyyaṃ'.
dānamuttamaṃ.translation_1: I would give the supreme gift.

akitticariyaṃ.meaning_2: infamous conduct; disgraceful behavior; disrepute in action
akitticariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'akitticariyaṃ paṭhamaṃ', the word is the neuter accusative singular of the compound, serving as the object of paṭhamaṃ ('first'), likely indicating 'infamous conduct first' or 'beginning with disreputable behavior' in a list or sequence of vices.

saṅkhacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of calculation; numerological behavior; way of enumeration
saṅkhacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where saṅkhā (calculation, enumeration) modifies cariyā (conduct, behavior), likely referring to a specific practice or ethical conduct involving counting or computation in Buddhist contexts, such as in meditation or doctrinal enumeration.

punāparaṃ.meaning_2: again and again; repeatedly; then again
punāparaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The adverb punāparaṃ functions as a compound of puna 'again' and aparaṃ 'furthermore, later', emphasizing repetition or sequential occurrences in narratives, as seen in the contextual translations like 'Then again when I was' or 'Later on', indicating multiple instances or times.

saṅkhasavhayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound saṅkhasavhayo functions as a proper name in the vocative case, addressing a brahmin named Saṅkha, where 'saṅkha' refers to the name and 'savhaya' means 'called' or 'named'.

kantāraddhānapaṭipannaṃ.meaning_2: practising the dangerous path; gone along the wilderness road
kantāraddhānapaṭipannaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound describing someone who has entered or is following a perilous path through the wilderness, often used metaphorically for a risky spiritual or existential journey.

kaṭhinabhūmiyā.meaning_2: ground that is rough and hard; rough and hard ground
kaṭhinabhūmiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, the compound describes the ground of a place as being both hot (implied by 'tattāya' meaning 'of that', referring to a hot location) and rough/hard, emphasizing the harsh terrain.
kaṭhinabhūmiyā.translation_1: whose ground was hot and rough.

vicintayiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, 'vicintayiṃ' expresses the act of mental reflection or consideration, as in 'I thought this' and 'I thought of giving gifts', indicating past deliberation.

mahāgamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'khettaṃ disvā mahāgamaṃ' meaning 'seeing a fertile field', mahāgamaṃ is the accusative singular of a compound referring to a large village or town, likely the object of seeing, indicating a prosperous settlement associated with the fertile field.

khettavaruttamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'khettavaruttamaṃ' refers to a supreme or excellent field, likely metaphorical for a field of merit or kamma, as seen in Buddhist texts where 'khetta' denotes a field of action or existence.

muddikāmo.meaning_2: one seeking the royal seal; minister desiring the seal
muddikāmo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'muddikāmo' describes an amacco (minister) who is seeking or desiring the king's muddikā (seal), used metaphorically for someone aspiring to authority or office.
muddikāmo.translation_1: Or suppose a minister seeking the royal seal

muddito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'muddito parihāyati', muddito functions as a present participle agreeing with an implied masculine subject, meaning 'being delighted' or 'gladdened', where the authority (of the subject) dwindles despite or because of this state.

adāsahanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form adāsahanti is the 3rd singular present of an irregular verb adāsahati 'to give', used here in quotative contexts with 'ti' to report statements of giving, as in 'I gave to him/it'.
adāsahanti.translation_1: I gave like this to him.”
adāsahanti.translation_2: which is why I gave away the elephant.’”

saṅkhacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of calculation; behavior involving enumeration
saṅkhacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'saṅkhacariyaṃ dutiyaṃ', this neuter accusative form refers to the second instance or section of conduct related to calculation or enumeration, likely in a Vinaya or grammatical classification of behaviors.

kururājacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'kururāja' (cruel king) is qualified by 'cariyā' (conduct). The form is feminine nominative singular, likely functioning adjectivally or as a descriptive noun.

dasahupāgato.meaning_2: reached with ten days; attained ten days; blessed with the ten skillful deeds
dasahupāgato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'kusale dasahupāgato' translated as 'I was blessed with the ten skillful deeds', the compound dasahupāgato appears to be a contextual or interpretive form where 'dasa' refers to ten, 'ha' may indicate a sense of 'skillful' or 'good', and 'upāgato' means attained or reached. This suggests attainment of ten virtuous or skillful states or deeds, possibly an idiomatic expression in the text.
dasahupāgato.translation_1: I was blessed with the ten skillful deeds.

kaliṅgaraṭṭhavisayā.meaning_2: from the realm of Kaliṅga; from the country of Kaliṅga
kaliṅgaraṭṭhavisayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the ablative singular of the compound noun, indicating origin from the region or domain of the Kaliṅga kingdom, as used in the provided sentences.

upagañchu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'brāhmaṇā upagañchu maṃ', upagañchu is the 3rd plural present indicative of upagañchati, meaning 'they approach me' or 'they come to me', referring to the brahmins approaching the speaker.

maṅgalasammataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, maṅgalasammataṃ describes 'dhaññaṃ' (that) as something fortunate and regarded as bringing good fortune or prosperity, aligning with maṅgala's core sense of auspiciousness.
maṅgalasammataṃ.translation_1: that was lucky and deemed auspicious.
maṅgalasammataṃ.translation_2: that was lucky and deemed as auspicious.

añjanasavhayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound adjective describing something (likely a horse or similar) as having a pitch-black color and being named Añjana, based on the context of 'midnight hue'.

yācakamanuppatte.meaning_2: when supplicants come; at the arrival of mendicants
yācakamanuppatte.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the compound 'yācakamanuppatta', used adverbially in the phrase to indicate the circumstance 'when supplicants come to me', as seen in the contextual sentences. The compound combines 'yācaka' (beggar) with 'anuppatta' (having arrived), forming a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'the arrival of a supplicant'.

ratanāmaye.meaning_2: made of jewels; bejeweled; adorned with gems
ratanāmaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'ratanāmaye' is a locative form of the adjective describing the ceremonial vessel (bhiṅgāre), indicating it is made of or adorned with jewels, hence 'bejeweled'.

padassasi.meaning_2: you may abandon; you could abandon; you should abandon
padassasi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'yācakānaṃ padassasi' ('to the supplicants, you may abandon?'), the word functions as an optative form expressing a potential or recommended action of abandoning or giving up, likely in relation to the supplicants (yācakānaṃ). The prefix 'pa-' from pada may imply direction or relation to 'feet' or 'steps,' but the core meaning derives from assati (abandons).

maṅgalasampannaṃ.meaning_2: endowed with the auspicious; possessing blessings and prosperity
maṅgalasampannaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'maṅgalasampannaṃ' describes someone fortunate and fully equipped with auspicious qualities, aligning with the English translation of luck and auspicious endowment. The compound combines 'maṅgala' (auspiciousness) with 'sampanna' (endowed), emphasizing completeness in positive attributes.
maṅgalasampannaṃ.translation_1: He was lucky and endowed with the auspicious,

saṅgāmavijayuttamaṃ.meaning_2: supreme victor in battle; supreme triumph in war
saṅgāmavijayuttamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular masculine, used as a title or epithet describing the supreme victor in battle, as per the English translation.

dajjamattano.meaning_2: to be given for oneself; to be offered to oneself; one's own body to be given
dajjamattano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'sarīraṃ dajjamattano' translated as 'and my physical body as well', the form dajjamattano functions as a sandhi compound where dajja (potential ptp of dadāti, meaning 'to be given') combines with attano (gen sg of atta, 'of oneself'), implying the body belonging to oneself that should be given or offered, likely in a sense of dedication or surrender in the discourse.
dajjamattano.translation_1: and my physical body as well.

kururājacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of the king of Kuru
kururājacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a compound noun referring to the third (tatiyaṃ) section or topic, likely the conduct or story of the king of the Kuru country in a narrative or doctrinal context.

mahāsudassanacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the great king Sudassana
mahāsudassanacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of a sutta in the Dīgha Nikāya describing the righteous conduct and life of the ancient king Mahāsudassana, a previous incarnation of the Buddha.

kusāvatimhi.meaning_2: name of the royal capital of king Mahāsudassana; lit. having lots of kusa grass
kusāvatimhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, 'kusāvatimhi' is the locative singular form of 'kusāvatī', indicating the location 'in the city of Kusāvatī'. The form 'kusāvatimhi' combines the locative 'kusāvatim' with the enclitic 'hi' meaning 'indeed' or 'in'. The city is a proper name in Buddhist texts, often associated with the legendary king Mahāsudassana.

dīyatū.meaning_2: be given; ought to be given
dīyatū.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'kassa kiṃ dīyatū dhanaṃ', dīyatū functions as an optative expressing obligation or propriety, indicating that riches 'ought to be given' to someone, with dhanaṃ as the object to be given.
dīyatū.translation_1: To whom ought riches be given?

chattamādeti.meaning_2: takes an umbrella; carries a parasol
chattamādeti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'chattamādeti' refers to carrying or taking an umbrella along on a journey, likely for protection from rain or sun, as implied by the rhetorical question about doing so on a highway.
chattamādeti.translation_1: Who will take an umbrella on a highway,

kopāhanā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'kopāhanā mudū subhā’, the word refers to sandals that are soft and pretty, likely in a vocative form addressing or offering them. The compound combines 'kopa' (possibly a variant or error for 'pāda' meaning foot) with 'āhana' (related to striking or covering), but contextually denotes footwear.
kopāhanā.translation_1: who needs sandals, soft and pretty?’

ṭhānasatesu.meaning_2: hundred places; hundred positions; hundred cases
ṭhānasatesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'napi ṭhānasatesu vā', it denotes 'even in a hundred places' or 'even in a hundred cases', emphasizing abundance or multiplicity, likely referring to places, positions, or instances where something does not occur.

anekasataṭhānesu.meaning_1: consisting of many hundreds of places
anekasataṭhānesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form anekasataṭhānesu is the locative plural of the compound adjective anekasataṭhāna, used here to indicate location in numerous places, matching the English translation 'but in many hundreds of places'. The base ṭhāna primarily means 'place' in this physical sense.
anekasataṭhānesu.translation_1: but in many hundreds of places

pūrahatthova.meaning_2: with full hands only; carrying full hands
pūrahatthova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound pūrahatthova functions adverbially in the sentence, modifying gacchati to indicate the manner of leaving: departing with hands full, emphasized by eva as 'only' or 'just' in this state, implying abundance or satisfaction in departure.

napāhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'napāhaṃ dessaṃ dhanaṃ dammi', 'napāhaṃ' negates the first person pronoun 'ahaṃ' (I), resulting in 'I did not' as the subject of the clause, where the speaker denies giving wealth due to dislike.
napāhaṃ.translation_1: I did not give because I disliked riches,

paripūretumasesato.meaning_2: in order to fulfill without remainder; completely; fully
paripūretumasesato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be an adverbial phrase combining the infinitive paripūretuṃ ('to fulfill') with the adverb asesato ('without remainder'), used to express purpose in a complete, exhaustive manner, as reflected in the English translation.
paripūretumasesato.translation_1: in order to fulfill without remainder,

ūnamanaṃ.meaning_2: deficiency of mind; what is lacking in the mind; mental shortcoming
ūnamanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'ūnamanaṃ pūrayituṃ', it refers to fulfilling the mental deficiencies or lacks in understanding or virtue, as per the English translation 'to fulfill what is lacking'.

pūrayituṃ.meaning_2: to fill; to fulfill; to complete; to supply what is lacking
pūrayituṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of ūnamanaṃ pūrayituṃ, the infinitive denotes the purpose 'to fulfill what is lacking' or 'to supply deficiencies', often used in ethical or doctrinal contexts in Pāḷi texts.

sambodhimanupattiyāti.meaning_2: attainment of awakening; attainment of enlightenment
sambodhimanupattiyāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form in the text is the instrumental singular of the compound noun, used in the phrase 'sambodhimanupattiyāti' to denote the purpose 'for the attainment of awakening' as per the English translation.

mahāsudassanacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of the great king Sudassana
mahāsudassanacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Accusative singular form used as title of the fourth chapter in the Cariyāpiṭaka, referring to the exemplary conduct of the Buddha's previous incarnation as King Mahāsudassana.

mahāgovindacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the great Govinda; way of behaving of Jotipāla
mahāgovindacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'mahāgovinda' (epithet of Jotipāla) is qualified by 'cariyā' meaning conduct or behavior. In context, it likely refers to the exemplary life or conduct of Jotipāla, known as Mahāgovinda.

sattarājapurohito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a title or role, literally 'priest placed before seven kings,' indicating service as chief priest across multiple reigns, consistent with the English translation.

mahāgovindabrāhmaṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound referring to the brahmin named Mahāgovinda, used in vocative case to address him directly in the context.

sattarajjesu.meaning_2: seven kingdoms; seven realms of sovereignty
sattarajjesu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'tadāhaṃ sattarajjesu', this locative plural form indicates 'in/among the seven kingdoms', referring to multiple domains of rulership as translated in the English sentence.

mahāgovindacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of the great Govinda; (fifth chapter/section)
mahāgovindacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Accusative singular form used as object, likely referring to the fifth chapter of the Cariyāpiṭaka titled 'Mahāgovindacariya'; epithet mahāgovinda applies to Jotipāla, a previous birth of the Buddha as a wise minister.

nimirājacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound referring to the story or conduct of King Nimi, a previous birth of the Buddha, as found in the Jātaka tales.

kusalatthiko.meaning_2: skilled in what is beneficial; seeking the good; astute
kusalatthiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'paṇḍito kusalatthiko', the compound describes someone who is wise and focused on wholesome or beneficial aims, aligning with the English translation 'astute and seeking the good'. The first member 'kusala' emphasizes skill or wholesomeness, while 'atthika' indicates seeking benefit or advantage.

māpayitvāna.meaning_2: having had constructed; having caused to measure; having ordered to build
māpayitvāna.construction: mā + √pā > māp + a + ya + tvā + na
māpayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'tadāhaṃ māpayitvāna', the absolutive form indicates an action completed by the speaker ('I') prior to the main clause, meaning 'then I, having had it constructed' or 'after having arranged for the construction'.

catussālaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'catu' (four) modifies 'sālā' (hall), and the accusative form indicates it as an object in the sentence. The phrase 'catummukhaṃ' (four-faced, with four openings) provides a descriptive parallel, emphasizing the architectural feature of halls open on all four sides.

catummukhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'catummukhaṃ' describes a structure with four halls each having four openings, likely referring to an architectural feature like a quadrangular hall with entrances on all four sides.

migapakkhinarādinaṃ.meaning_2: beasts, birds, men, and so forth; etc.; and the rest
migapakkhinarādinaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a genitive plural form of a compound noun indicating a class of beings starting with beasts (miga), birds (pakkhī), and men (nara), followed by etc. (ādī), used in the context to denote 'for beasts, birds, men, and so forth'.
migapakkhinarādinaṃ.translation_1: for beasts, birds, men, and so forth.

dhanahetumupāgato.meaning_2: approached for the sake of wealth; gone to for riches; attained by reason of money
dhanahetumupāgato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound dhanahetumupāgato describes someone who has approached or attained something for the sake of wealth, aligning with the context of seeking a raise from the boss, where 'dhana' implies monetary gain and 'hetu' the motivating cause.
dhanahetumupāgato.translation_1: to get a raise from their boss,

ārādhanīyamesati.meaning_2: is to be fulfilled by body, speech, and mind
ārādhanīyamesati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ārādhanīyamesati results from sandhi where the accusative singular neuter ārādhanīyaṃ ('what is to be accomplished') combines with the 3sg present esati ('seeks'). In context, it idiomatically expresses the idea of something being sought or fulfilled through physical actions (body), verbal actions (speech), and mental actions (mind), as a unified concept of complete devotion or practice.

bodhimuttamanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound used as an indeclinable adverbial accusative, modifying 'bodhi' in the sentence, indicating the aspiration for the highest state of enlightenment, as in the Buddha's vow.
bodhimuttamanti.translation_1: I wish for the supreme awakening.”

nimirājacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'nimirājacariyaṃ chaṭṭhaṃ', this term refers to the sixth Cariyāpiṭaka chapter detailing the Buddha's previous life conduct as King Nimi.

candakumāracariyā.meaning_2: conduct of Prince Canda; story of the conduct of the moon prince
candakumāracariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'cariyā' (conduct) is qualified by 'candakumāra' (Prince Canda), likely referring to a narrative episode in the Jātaka tales involving the previous birth of Sāriputta as Prince Canda.

ekarājassa.meaning_2: of the One King; of the sole sovereign
ekarājassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'ekarājassa' is the genitive singular form used to indicate possession in 'the true-born son of the One King', where 'One King' likely refers to a unique or supreme ruler, such as a universal monarch or divine figure in Pāḷi literature.
ekarājassa.translation_1: the true-born son of the One King

candasavhayo.meaning_2: Prince Canda; the one called Canda, the Moon
candasavhayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound in instrumental singular, used in the sentence 'kumāro candasavhayo' meaning 'I was called Prince Canda, the Moon.' The form shows sandhi resolution of 'canda + savhāyena' or similar, functioning as a descriptive title for the speaker's former name.
candasavhayo.translation_1: I was called Prince Canda, the Moon.

janayitvāna.meaning_2: having caused; having produced; having given rise to
janayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'saṃvegaṃ janayitvāna', it means having produced or aroused a sense of urgency (saṃvega), functioning as an absolutive to indicate the action preceding the main verb.
janayitvāna.translation_1: Giving rise to a sense of urgency,

adatvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'dakkhiṇeyye adatvāna' meaning 'without having given to one worthy of gifts', it indicates the reason or condition for an action persisting over five or six days, implying neglect or omission of donation.

chappañcarattiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is nominative plural of a feminine compound noun, used here in a context implying a period of five or six nights following the first offering to a worthy recipient.
chappañcarattiyo.translation_1: with having first offering to a worthy recipient.

bhaṇḍasañcayaṃ.meaning_2: store of goods; accumulation of merchandise
bhaṇḍasañcayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, bhaṇḍasañcayaṃ functions as the object of katvāna, indicating a collection or store of goods amassed by the subject, fitting the context of 'who had made a store of goods'.
bhaṇḍasañcayaṃ.translation_1: who had made a store of goods.

sakabhuttāpi.meaning_2: one's own that has been used oneself; one's own that has been enjoyed oneself
sakabhuttāpi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'sakabhuttāpi' modifies an implied object of giving, indicating that even something previously used or enjoyed by the giver oneself can be meritorious when given away. The instrumental form 'sakabhuttā' agrees with the feminine or neuter object, and 'api' adds the sense of 'even' to emphasize inclusivity.
sakabhuttāpi.translation_1: So too, even giving what one has used oneself

satabhāgo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'satabhāgo bhavissati', the compound functions adverbially to indicate multiplication by one hundred, i.e., 'becomes a hundredfold' or 'increases a hundred times', aligning with the English translation 'multiplies a hundredfold'.

candakumāracariyaṃ.meaning_2: the conduct of Prince Canda; the story of Prince Canda's meritorious deeds
candakumāracariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a compound noun referring to the seventh chapter of the Cariyāpiṭaka, which narrates the meritorious conduct of Prince Canda, a previous birth of Sāriputta. The title indicates the specific 'story of conduct' focused on this incarnation.

sivirājacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the Sivī king; royal conduct of the king of Sivī
sivirājacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (tatpuruṣa) where 'sivī' refers to the king or country, 'rāja' means king, and 'cariyā' denotes conduct or behavior, likely alluding to a specific narrative in Pāḷi literature involving the king of Sivī known for his generosity.

ariṭṭhasavhaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ariṭṭhasavhaye is the locative singular of the compound ariṭṭhasavhaya, where ariṭṭha functions as a proper name for the city (lit. 'unhurt') and savhaya means 'having the name' or 'called'. This construction is idiomatic in Pāḷi for naming places, equivalent to 'in the city known as Ariṭṭha'.

sivināmāsi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sivināmāsi is a fused expression equivalent to 'sivī nāma asi', meaning 'you are (the one) named Sivi', functioning as a predicate nominative in the context of identifying oneself as the aristocrat Sivi.
sivināmāsi.translation_1: I was the aristocrat named Sivi.

cintesahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed by combining the 1st person singular aorist of cinteti (cintesi, 'I thought') with the pronoun ahaṃ ('I'), resulting in cintesahaṃ. It expresses a past reflective thought, as seen in the contextual translations like 'I then had the following thought' or 'I thought to myself', indicating internal contemplation at that time or place.
cintesahaṃ.translation_1: I then had the following thought:

devānamissaro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where devānaṃ (genitive plural of deva, 'of the gods') is combined with issara ('lord'), forming a bahuvrīhi-like possessive meaning 'lord of the gods'. In the context, it identifies Sakka as the ruler of the deities.

sivirājā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the nominative singular form of the compound 'sivirājā', referring to the legendary King Sivi, known in Pāḷi texts for his generosity and virtue, as indicated by the English translation 'the mighty King Sivi'.

vīmaṃsayāmi.meaning_2: I investigate; I examine; I test
vīmaṃsayāmi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'handa vīmaṃsayāmi taṃ', the 1st person singular present form expresses the speaker's intention to test or examine 'him' (taṃ), aligning with the English translation 'Come, let us test him.' The desiderative nature ('desires to know') fits the context of proposing an investigation.

palitasiro.meaning_2: old man; one with grey hair
palitasiro.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'palitasiro' is a compound functioning as a noun describing someone appearing as a frail old man, with 'palita' indicating grey/hoary hair (symbolizing age) and 'sīro' as head, hence 'grey-headed' or 'old'.
palitasiro.translation_1: Appearing as a frail old man,

valigatto.meaning_2: with grey hair and wrinkled skin
valigatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound valigatto describes the physical signs of old age, combining 'vali' (wrinkles or grey hair) and 'gatta' (bodily features), as seen in the context of aging.
valigatto.translation_1: with grey hair and wrinkled skin,

valitagatto.meaning_1: wrinkled with limbs; furrowed having body parts
valitagatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound adjective combining the past participle 'valita' (wrinkled, furrowed) with 'gatta' (having limbs or body parts), possibly used in a context describing a physical state or form, such as a wrinkled body or figure with prominent limbs. Without the specific sentence, the exact contextual nuance is inferred from the dictionary entries.

jarāturo.meaning_2: old; aged; decrepit; with signs of old age
jarāturo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound jarāturo describes a state of old age marked by physical decay, as seen in the context of grey hair (valigatto) and wrinkled skin, evoking the impermanence of the body in Pāḷi texts.
jarāturo.translation_1: with grey hair and wrinkled skin,

andhavaṇṇova.meaning_2: only blind and feeble; just sightless and weak
andhavaṇṇova.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form andhavaṇṇova is a sandhi compound functioning as an indeclinable emphatic expression, combining 'andha' (blind) and 'vaṇṇa' (colour, here implying vigour or appearance) with 'eva' (only). In the context of the sentence, it describes a state of being utterly feeble and blind, emphasizing total lack of sight and vitality, as in a weakened or diminished condition.

paggahetvāna.meaning_2: having taken; having stretched out; having raised
paggahetvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the first sentence, 'paggahetvāna' means 'having stretched out' (likely hands or arms in a gesture), while in the second it means 'having raised' joined palms in reverence. The -na ending is an old instrumental form used adverbially with absolutive.

dakkhiṇabāhu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, dakkhiṇabāhu refers to the right arm, contrasting with vāma (left arm), as part of describing the arms of a person or being.

dānaratā.grammar: adj, in comps, from dadāti + ramati
dānaratā.meaning_2: love of giving; delight in generosity
dānaratā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word dānaratā functions as a feminine nominative singular adjective describing a quality of delight or devotion to giving, as seen in the contexts: 'tava dānaratā kitti' (the renown of your love of giving) and 'sadā dānaratā ahu' (always delighted in giving), emphasizing habitual generosity.
dānaratā.translation_1: and the renown of your love of giving
dānaratā.translation_2: my mother always delighted in giving.

saṃviggamānaso.meaning_2: with elated mind; thrilled in mind; mentally uplifted
saṃviggamānaso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'saṃviggamānaso' describes a state of mental exhilaration and thrill, contrasting the dictionary's typical senses of agitation or awe; here it conveys positive elation, as in being mentally uplifted or overjoyed.
saṃviggamānaso.translation_1: I was thrilled, my mind elated,
saṃviggamānaso.translation_2: I was thrilled, my mind elated,

vacanamabraviṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word 'vacanamabraviṃ' appears to be a sandhi form of 'vacanaṃ abraviṃ', where 'vacanaṃ' is the accusative singular of 'vacana' (nt, meaning 'word; utterance'), and 'abraviṃ' is the 1st person singular aorist of 'brūti' ('to say'). In the given sentences, it translates as 'I said the following' or 'and said the following', introducing a direct speech or statement.

dānavaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, dānavaraṃ refers to an exceptional or supreme gift that the speaker pledges to offer to a supplicant or directly to 'you', emphasizing generosity in a ritual or charitable act.
dānavaraṃ.translation_1: Today I shall give to a supplicant
dānavaraṃ.translation_2: Today I shall give to you

dandhayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the prohibitive context 'mā dandhayi', it functions as an imperative form meaning 'do not hesitate', paralleling 'mā pavedhayi' which also means 'do not waver'. This usage conveys a command against indecision or faltering in action.

pavedhayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the prohibitive construction 'mā pavedhayi', it functions as a negative imperative meaning 'do not waver', paralleling 'mā dandhayi' (do not hesitate), emphasizing resolve in action or faith.

uddharitvāna.meaning_2: having extracted; having taken out; having uprooted
uddharitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'uddharitvāna pādāsi' means 'having extracted, he gave the eyes,' referring to the act of removing or taking out both eyes, likely in a narrative of self-mutilation or punishment as seen in Vinaya stories.

tālamiñjaṃva.meaning_2: trembling; quivering like a palm kernel
tālamiñjaṃva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound tālamiñjaṃ functions as an adjective modifying yācake 'supplicant' in the accusative singular. It describes a state of trembling or quivering, likely comparing the supplicant's fear to the subtle vibration of a palm kernel or fruit in the wind. The particle va adds emphasis, meaning 'even' or 'indeed', intensifying the description of the supplicant's condition as he receives the presentation.
tālamiñjaṃva.translation_1: he presented them to the trembling supplicant.

dinnadānassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'dinnadānassa me sato', this genitive form refers to the act or object of having given, recalling the merit or mindfulness of the giving in a reflective or meditative sense, likely in a sutta on generosity.

sivirājacariyaṃ.meaning_2: the conduct of King Sivī; the story of King Sivī
sivirājacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Refers to the eighth (aṭṭhamaṃ) in a series, likely a Jātaka or similar narrative about the conduct or story of King Sivī, known for his generosity in Buddhist texts.

vessantaracariyā.meaning_2: conduct of Vessantara; the story of Vessantara's perfection
vessantaracariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound refers to the Jātaka tale of Vessantara, one of the ten perfections (pāramī) in Buddhist literature, emphasizing the perfection of giving (dāna). The form is feminine nominative singular, likely the title or subject of the narrative.

phussatī.meaning_2: proper name of an aristocrat lady
phussatī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Appears as the subject in vocative or nominative case, referring to the lady Phussatī in the narrative context of her life and passing.
phussatī.translation_2: Phussatī was blessed with the ten favors.

varabhadde.meaning_2: excellent lady; dear lady; good lady
varabhadde.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Vocative singular form used as a polite address to an esteemed woman, combining 'vara' (excellent, best) with 'bhaddā' (lady, madam), translating contextually as 'my dear' in the sentence offering a favor.
varabhadde.translation_1: my dear, whatever favor you wish.’

punidamabravi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form punidamabravi is a sandhi combination of puna (again), idaṃ (this), and abravi (said), functioning as a finite aorist verb meaning 'replied again to this' or 'said this again', addressing Sakka in the context of the sentence.

aparādhatthi.meaning_2: is there a fault; is there an offence; is there a deficiency
aparādhatthi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a compound of aparādha (fault, offence) and atthi (there is), functioning as a present tense verb meaning 'is there a fault?'. In the context, it expresses self-questioning about deficiency or wrongdoing.

dharaṇīruhaṃ.meaning_2: growing thing of the earth; plant; tree; feeble tree
dharaṇīruhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'like the wind a feeble tree', dharaṇīruhaṃ refers to a tree or plant as something fragile that sways under the influence of wind, emphasizing vulnerability or weakness.
dharaṇīruhaṃ.translation_1: like the wind a feeble tree.’

tassidamabravi.meaning_2: replied to her; said this to her
tassidamabravi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tassidamabravi results from sandhi resolution of tassa idaṃ abravī, where the adverbial phrase 'tassa idaṃ' (to her this) functions as the indirect object, and abravī is the 3sg aorist of brūti, conveying 'replied' in the narrative context of the English translation.

dinnavarā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'dinnavarā' refers to the excellent or choice offerings given by Sakka, which the female subject accepts. The compound combines 'dinna' (given, offering) with 'varā' (excellent, feminine form agreeing with the subject).
dinnavarā.translation_1: She accepted the offerings of Sakka,

tuṭṭhahaṭṭhā.meaning_2: full of joy and happiness; delighted and content
tuṭṭhahaṭṭhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound adjective formed from tuṭṭha (content, pleased, from √tus) and haṭṭhā (joyful, elated, from √haṃs), used in the nominative feminine singular to describe a state of being pleased and joyful, matching the English translation 'full of joy and happiness' in the provided sentence.

varī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'dasa vare varī' indicates 'blessed with the ten favors' or 'endowed with ten boons', where varī is an irregular form functioning as a past participle meaning 'endowed with' or 'blessed with', agreeing with Phussatī.
varī.translation_1: Phussatī was blessed with the ten favors.

jetuttaramhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word 'jetuttaramhi' is the locative singular form of the compound 'jetuttara', used here to denote 'in the city of Jetuttara'. 'Jeta' relates to a conqueror (from √ji), and 'uttara' means 'higher' or 'northern', suggesting a place name possibly meaning 'higher Jetuttara' or 'northern conqueror's city'.

phussatiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'yadāhaṃ phussatiyā kucchiṃ', 'phussatiyā' is the instrumental singular form of 'phussa', meaning 'by the womb' or 'in the womb', indicating the location of conception as translated in English.
phussatiyā.translation_1: Once I was conceived in the womb

piyamātuyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form piyamātuyā is a tatpuruṣa compound in the genitive singular, used to express possession in the context 'of my dear mother Phussatī'. The base mātuyā is the genitive of mātū, an extended form of mātā (mother).

dhārayitvāna.meaning_2: having held; having carried; having borne
dhārayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the first sentence, it denotes the mother having carried the child in the womb for ten months; in the second, holding the white umbrella; in the third, after holding the umbrella for seven days. The form dhārayitvāna shows -na extension typical in some texts for emphasis or stylistic reasons, equivalent to standard dhārayitvā.
dhārayitvāna.translation_1: Having carried me for ten months,
dhārayitvāna.translation_2: Holding a white umbrella over my bed,

pettikasambhavaṃ.meaning_2: origin from the father; paternal descent
pettikasambhavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'napi pettikasambhavaṃ' translated as 'nor from my father’s', the term refers to the origin or source linked to the father's side, likely paternal lineage or inheritance, negated by 'na'.

jātettha.meaning_2: born here; born in this place
jātettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'jātettha' functions as an adverbial compound indicating the location of birth, literally 'born here' or 'born in that place', referring to the peasant's street.
jātettha.translation_1: I was born there in the peasant’s street,

vessavīthiyā.meaning_2: peasant’s street; street of the merchant and agricultural caste
vessavīthiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'jātettha vessavīthiyā' ('I was born there in the peasant’s street'), the term refers to a specific street or quarter inhabited by the vessa caste, known for merchant and agricultural occupations.
vessavīthiyā.translation_1: I was born there in the peasant’s street,

aṭṭhavassiko.grammar: adj, in comps, from aṭṭha + vassa
aṭṭhavassiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'jātiyā aṭṭhavassiko', it describes someone who is eight years of age by birth, indicating young age, often in legal or monastic contexts for eligibility.

akampitamasaṇṭhitaṃ.meaning_2: undisturbed and steadfast; firm and unshaken
akampitamasaṇṭhitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the contextual sentences, the compound describes a state of mental composure, as in 'I was undisturbed and steadfast,' emphasizing firmness in the face of disturbances.

sineruvanavaṭaṃsakā.meaning_2: and Mount Sineru, wreathed in forests
sineruvanavaṭaṃsakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where sineru (Mount Meru) is qualified by vana (forests) and vaṭaṃsaka (wreathed/garlanded), forming an adjective agreeing with an implied masculine noun, portraying the mountain as adorned with forest garlands in the poetic context.
sineruvanavaṭaṃsakā.translation_1: and Mount Sineru, wreathed in forests.
sineruvanavaṭaṃsakā.translation_2: and Mount Sineru, wreathed in forests.

anvaddhamāse.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form anvaddhamāse is locative singular, indicating 'in every fortnight' or 'every half-month', corresponding to the temporal sense of 'every fortnight' in the sentence. The prefix anu here conveys the idea of 'every' or 'recurrently' in time, modifying the base noun addhamāsa ('fortnight').

nāgamāruyha.meaning_2: having mounted the elephant; having ascended the tusker
nāgamāruyha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'paccayaṃ nāgamāruyha' translated as 'I mounted the tusker Paccaya', the form is a compound gerund where nāga specifies the object of mounting (the elephant named Paccaya), and āruyha indicates the action of ascending or mounting it. This is a common Pāli construction for gerunds with objects.

nappatigūhāmi.meaning_2: I do not conceal; I do not hide
nappatigūhāmi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'santaṃ nappatigūhāmi', the verb means 'I do not hide what exists', indicating openness or non-concealment of knowledge or truth.
nappatigūhāmi.translation_1: I do not hide what I have,

nappatiguyhāmi.meaning_2: I do not conceal; I do not hide
nappatiguyhāmi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nappatiguhāmi is a first-person singular present indicative of the verb patiguhati (to conceal, hide) negated by na. The long ā in the ending is typical for ātmanepada verbs in the first person singular.

sivayo.meaning_2: townsfolk; citizens; inhabitants of a town
sivayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, 'sivayo' refers to the townsfolk or local inhabitants who are described as angry and gathering, or all responding when asked. This usage of 'siva' as 'townsfolk' is a common Pāli interpretation in narrative contexts, distinct from the primary meanings of 'auspicious' or the deity Shiva.
sivayo.translation_2: When I asked, all the townsfolk

nicchubhamānānaṃ.construction: na + iccha + ti + ubha + mān + ana
nicchubhamānānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a present participle in genitive plural masculine, describing the action of those who were in the process of ejecting the speaker, as per the contextual sentence. The compound combines 'niccha' (not desiring) with 'ubha' (both) and 'māna' (measuring or pride), but in this context, it idiomatically conveys the act of expulsion or removal.

akampitthamasaṇṭhitaṃ.meaning_2: unshaken and unattached; not trembled and not fixed
akampitthamasaṇṭhitaṃ.construction: akampi + ittha + a + saṃ + ṭhā + ita + a
akampitthamasaṇṭhitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective in neuter accusative singular, likely modifying a preceding noun such as 'cittaṃ' (mind) in a context emphasizing mental equanimity and non-attachment, common in Buddhist texts.

varamayācisaṃ.meaning_2: great offering; excellent gift; supreme oblation
varamayācisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'ekaṃ varamayācisaṃ', the word functions as the object of the infinitive 'to perform', indicating a singular great offering. The compound likely combines 'vara' (excellent), 'māyā' (from mā or māti, relating to measurement or honor), 'ci' (possessive or emphatic), and 'saṃ' (from saṃgha or offering), denoting a preeminent act of giving in a ritual or monastic context.

varamadaṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form varamadaṃsu is a 3rd person singular aorist derived from the causative stem varam + adāsi, meaning 'granted' or 'bestowed'. In the context 'ekaṃ varamadaṃsu me', it indicates that someone granted the speaker a single favor, with 'ekaṃ' as the direct object and 'me' as the dative indirect object.

sāvayitvā.meaning_2: having caused to sound; having made resound
sāvayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'Sounding the drums', sāvayitvā functions as an absolutive indicating the manner or prior action of causing the drums (kaṇṇabheriṃ) to sound, often used for instruments in Pāḷi to imply producing sound.

kaṇṇabheriṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'kaṇṇabheriṃ' is the accusative singular of this compound noun, used as the object of 'sāvayitvā', referring to a drum that is sounded, likely a type of kettledrum associated with the ear or perhaps a metaphorical or specific term for a signaling drum.

dadāmahaṃ.meaning_2: I give; I offer; I donate
dadāmahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dadāmahaṃ is the 1st person singular present indicative of dadāti 'gives', combined with the enclitic pronoun ahaṃ 'I' for emphasis. In the sentence mahādānaṃ dadāmahaṃ, it translates as 'I gave a great offering', though the form is present tense, possibly indicating narrative or emphatic style in Pāḷi.

dānenimaṃ.meaning_2: because of this giving; on account of this charity
dānenimaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental form of 'dāna' (giving, charity) combined with the accusative pronoun 'imaṃ' (this), functioning as an adverbial phrase explaining the reason for being driven out in the sentence 'dānenimaṃ nīharanti'.
dānenimaṃ.translation_1: They drove me out because of giving,

dadātayaṃ.meaning_2: I give; I offer; I donate
dadātayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'puna dānaṃ dadātayaṃ', the form dadātayaṃ is the 1st person singular present indicative of dadāti, meaning 'I give' or 'I am giving', corresponding to the English 'I just gave again', which reflects a present perfect nuance in the context of repeated action.

daditvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, it indicates the action of giving completed prior to the main action, as in 'after giving this great gift'.

catuvāhiṃ.meaning_2: having four horses; drawn by four horses
catuvāhiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'catuvāhiṃ rathaṃ' refers to a chariot drawn by four horses, with 'catuvāhiṃ' as the accusative singular masculine/neuter adjective modifying 'rathaṃ' (chariot). The form shows sandhi resolution from 'catu-vāhiṃ'.
catuvāhiṃ.translation_1: Having given away my four-horse chariot,

maddideviṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, 'maddideviṃ' is the accusative singular form of the compound 'maddī devī', referring to Queen Maddī. The first member 'maddī' is the name of the princess/queen, daughter of king Madda, and 'devī' specifies her as queen. The form ends in -ṃ due to accusative case, used as the object in sentences like 'I said to Queen Maddī' and 'He asked me for Queen Maddī'.
maddideviṃ.translation_1: and I said to Queen Maddī:
maddideviṃ.translation_2: He asked me for Queen Maddī,

idamabraviṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the form idamabraviṃ, it is the 1st person singular aorist of brūti, meaning 'I said this' or 'I spoke thus', used in the context of addressing someone as in the provided sentences: 'and I said to Queen Maddī', 'this to that spirit', 'I said to him'.
idamabraviṃ.translation_1: and I said to Queen Maddī:

kaniṭṭhikā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'kaniṭṭhikā' refers to the speaker's younger sister, who is described as 'lighter' (lahukā), possibly in weight, status, or burden.
kaniṭṭhikā.translation_1: for she, as the younger sister, is the lighter.

kaṇhājinaggahī.meaning_2: picked up Kaṇhājinā; took hold of the princess Kaṇhājinā
kaṇhājinaggahī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aggahī is the 3rd sg. aorist of gaṇhāti, equivalent to aggahi in the dictionary but with i-ending typical for feminine subjects or certain dialects/contexts. In the sentence, Maddī (feminine subject) performs the action of grasping or picking up the princess Kaṇhājinā.

suvaṇṇabimbaṃva.meaning_2: like a golden image; like a golden statue
suvaṇṇabimbaṃva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a sandhi form of suvaṇṇabimbaṃ iva, used in simile construction to compare the speaker to a golden image or statue, emphasizing beauty or luster.

khattiyamaggahiṃ.meaning_2: I took; I grasped; I picked up
khattiyamaggahiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form aggahiṃ is the 1st person singular aorist of gaṇhāti, indicating the action of picking up or grasping Jāli, the aristocrat, in the context of the sentence.
khattiyamaggahiṃ.translation_1: I picked up Jāli, the aristocrat.

anumagge.meaning_2: coming the other way along the road
anumagge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the locative singular form anumagge, it describes location 'along the road' in the context of someone coming from the opposite direction, as per the English translation.
anumagge.translation_1: coming the other way along the road,

paṭippathe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the locative singular form paṭippathe, it denotes 'along the path' or 'on the way', as used in the context of traveling along the road.
paṭippathe.translation_1: coming the other way along the road,

vaṅkanta.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] vaṅkanta is a compound adjective formed from vaṅka (bent, from √vañc) + anta (ending in, in composition), meaning 'ending in a bend' or 'crooked at the end'. No specific contextual sentence provided, so general meaning applied.

giramudīrayuṃ.meaning_2: they spoke kindly; they uttered kind words
giramudīrayuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form giramudīrayuṃ is the 3rd plural aorist of udīrayati with giram as direct object, meaning 'they spoke up kind words' or 'they kindly spoke'. In context, it translates as 'they spoke to us kindly', with karuṇaṃ modifying the kindness of the speech.

vaṅkantapabbato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'vaṅkantapabbato' is a descriptive name for a specific mountain, combining 'vaṅka' (crooked, bent) with 'pabbato' (mountain), used in the locative case in the first sentence to ask its location, and nominative in the second to state it is far away.

uparodanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'uparodanti dārakā', the verb form uparodanti indicates that the children (dārakā) are crying, matching the English translation 'the children cried'. The form is present indicative 3rd plural active.

sayamevoṇamitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'sayamevoṇamitvāna' functions as an adverbial phrase modifying the action of bending down, indicating it occurred spontaneously without external influence. The form 'sayameva' is a fixed adverbial expression emphasizing self-initiated action.
sayamevoṇamitvāna.translation_1: bent down of their own accord,

sāhukāraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given Pāḷi sentence, 'sāhukāraṃ pavattesi' likely means 'he practiced as a merchant' or similar, where sāhukāraṃ is the accusative singular object referring to the role or profession of a merchant. The English sentence provided appears unrelated to this word's context.

sayamevoṇatā.meaning_2: bent down of one's own accord
sayamevoṇatā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where sayaṃ 'of one's own' modifies eva 'indeed', and the whole qualifies oṇatā 'bent down'. In the context of the sentence, it describes the trees bending down spontaneously without external force.
sayamevoṇatā.translation_1: the trees bent down of their own accord.’

nikkhantadivaseneva.meaning_2: on the very day of departure; on the day they set out
nikkhantadivaseneva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of the compound 'nikkhantadivasa' (day of departure) with the emphatic particle 'eva' appended, indicating 'on that very day' as per the context of setting out.
nikkhantadivaseneva.translation_1: so that on the very day they set out,

nikkhantadivaseyeva.meaning_2: on the very day of departure; just on the day he left
nikkhantadivaseyeva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound functioning adverbially: nikkhanta- (pp 'departed') + divasa- (masc/nt 'day') + eva ('just, only'). The form shows sandhi where final -a of divasa contracts with initial e- of eva to -e-, and the whole expresses 'precisely on the day of going out/departure'. Used temporally to indicate immediacy after departure.

cetaraṭṭhamupāgamuṃ.meaning_2: they arrived at the kingdom of Ceta
cetaraṭṭhamupāgamuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound where 'cetaraṭṭha' means 'the kingdom of Ceta' (ceta + raṭṭha), and 'upāgamuṃ' is the 3rd plural aorist of upāgacchati, indicating arrival in the past tense as used in the sentence.
cetaraṭṭhamupāgamuṃ.translation_1: they arrived at the kingdom of Ceta.

saṭṭhirājasahassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound numeral in the neuter plural accusative, used as the object in the sentence, denoting sixty thousand kings, likely in a hyperbolic or cosmological context common in Pāli literature.

cetaputtehi.meaning_2: with the folks of Ceta and their children
cetaputtehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound cetaputta, referring to the people of the Ceta country and their offspring, as used in the context of the sentence.
cetaputtehi.translation_1: with the folks of Ceta and their children.

āmantayitvā.meaning_2: having addressed; having called out to
āmantayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, āmantayitvā indicates the action of addressing that precedes the main clause, where the lord of gods speaks to someone.

sumāpaya.meaning_2: causes to measure well; makes well; builds well
sumāpaya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'paṇṇasālaṃ sumāpaya', it describes causing or having a hall of leaves to be built or constructed well, fitting the overall description of a well-made structure.

sumāpayi.meaning_2: having made; having prepared; having constructed
sumāpayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'paṇṇasālaṃ sumāpayi', it functions as an absolutive form meaning 'having made a hall of leaves', indicating the action completed before the main verb (implied in the narrative).

maddidevī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound maddidevī refers to Queen Maddī, the princess daughter of King Madda, used in the vocative case in the first sentence to address her directly, and in the locative case in the second sentence indicating 'for Queen Maddī'.

jūjake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, jūjake is the dative singular form addressing or indicating the brahmin named Jūjaka, as in 'to the brahmin Jūjaka'.

brāhmaṇasannibho.meaning_2: resembling a brahmin; in the guise of a brahmin
brāhmaṇasannibho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound adjective describes someone appearing or disguised as a brahmin, as seen in the contextual phrase 'in the guise of a brahmin', where it modifies an implied subject in the ablative or instrumental case.
brāhmaṇasannibho.translation_1: in the guise of a brahmin.

sīlavantiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sīlavantiṃ patibbataṃ', sīlavantiṃ is the accusative feminine singular form modifying a feminine noun (likely 'bhikkhuniṃ' or similar), describing someone as virtuous and devoted to precepts.

udakañjali.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound udakañjali refers to the act or position of cupping the hands with water, as indicated by the contextual phrase 'filling clasped hands with water'. Here, udaka provides the material (water), and añjali denotes the cupped hands used for holding it, often in ritual or respectful contexts.

pūriya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of udakañjali pūriya, it describes the action of filling clasped hands (añjali) with water (udaka), likely as part of a ritual or offering.

pasannamanasaṅkappo.meaning_2: intention with a confident heart; resolve born of confidence
pasannamanasaṅkappo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound functions as a bahuvrīhi, describing a type of intention or resolve characterized by a heart (or mind) that is confident or full of faith, aligning with the English translation 'with a confident heart' in the context of the sentence.

adāsahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentences, 'adāsahaṃ' is the 1st person singular aorist of 'deti' with the prefix 'ā-', meaning 'I gave'. It is used with an accusative object to indicate giving something (Maddī or loved ones) to someone.
adāsahaṃ.translation_2: I gave my loved ones away.

dhītaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, 'dhītaṃ' is the accusative singular form of 'dhītā', used vocatively to address the daughter Jāli and Kaṇhājinā in a familial or narrative context.

mātāpitusamāgame.meaning_2: reunion by mother and father; meeting arranged by parents
mātāpitusamāgame.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is locative singular of the compound mātāpitusamāgama, used to indicate the means or agency ('by') of the reunion in the context of the sentence.
mātāpitusamāgame.translation_1: we were reunited by my mother and father.

sañātibhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form sañātibhi used in the phrase to indicate accompaniment by family members, as in 'with my family' in the English translation.
sañātibhi.translation_1: having left the forest with my family,

jetuttaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Proper name of a city, formed as a compound of 'jeta' (conqueror, referencing a Buddha or victor) and 'uttara' (higher, superior, or northern), likely implying 'the superior Jetuttara' or 'northern Jetuttara'. In the sentence, it functions as the accusative singular object, translated as the capital city.

aviññāya.meaning_1: not knowing; without knowing; without understanding
aviññāya.meaning_2: without knowledge of; unaware of (happiness or sadness)
aviññāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'aviññāya sukhaṃ dukhaṃ', it describes a state of unconsciousness or unawareness, lacking perception of pleasure or pain, akin to deep sleep or insentience in Buddhist texts.
aviññāya.translation_1: with no knowledge of happiness or sadness,

dānabalā.grammar: adj, fem nom sg, in comps, from dadāti
dānabalā.meaning_2: powerful through giving; mighty by charity
dānabalā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'sāpi dānabalā mayhaṃ' translated as 'quaked seven times', 'dānabalā' likely describes the earth (sā, fem) as 'powerful through giving' or 'mighty by charity', indicating the strength derived from acts of generosity that causes the earth to quake seven times upon the Buddha's birth or similar event. The English translation appears to omit the word's descriptive role, focusing only on the action.

vessantaracariyaṃ.meaning_2: the conduct of Vessantara; the ninth Jātaka story
vessantaracariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Refers to the ninth of the ten great perfections (pāramī) exemplified in the Vessantara Jātaka, the story of the Buddha's previous birth as Prince Vessantara, who perfected the giving of dāna.

sasapaṇḍitacariyā.meaning_1: the conduct of a rabbit-like wise man
sasapaṇḍitacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of a wise man who is like a rabbit
sasapaṇḍitacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sasa' (rabbit) modifies 'paṇḍita' (wise man), and 'cariyā' (conduct) is the final member, likely idiomatic referring to a specific story or teaching involving a wise figure compared to a rabbit, possibly highlighting clever or cautious behavior.

sasako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word sasako is the nominative singular form of a masculine noun denoting a hare, used here as the subject of the sentence describing a hare that roams the forest.
sasako.translation_1: a hare who roamed the forest,

pavanacārako.meaning_2: one who roams the forest; forest wanderer
pavanacārako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, pavanacārako describes animals (hare, buffalo) that roam or wander in the forest, functioning as an epithet or descriptive compound.
pavanacārako.translation_1: a hare who roamed the forest,
pavanacārako.translation_2: a buffalo who roamed the forest,

tiṇapaṇṇasākaphalabhakkho.meaning_2: eating grass, leaves, vegetables, and fruit
tiṇapaṇṇasākaphalabhakkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound adjective qualifying a subject (likely an animal or ascetic) that subsists on a diet of grass, leaves, greens, and fruits, as per the contextual translation.
tiṇapaṇṇasākaphalabhakkho.translation_1: eating grass, leaves, vegetables, and fruit,

paraheṭhanavivajjito.meaning_2: refraining from harming others; free from harassing other people
paraheṭhanavivajjito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adjective where 'paraheṭhanā' (harming others) is qualified by 'vivajjita' (free from, avoided). In the given context, it describes the virtue of abstaining from harm to others, aligning with ethical precepts in Pāḷi texts.

suttapoto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'suttapoto cahaṃ tadā' translated as 'a young otter and I', suttapoto is a compound where sutta functions as an adjective 'sleeping' modifying pota 'young animal', specifically denoting a young otter. The translation reflects a contextual interpretation, possibly from a narrative like the Jātaka tales where the Buddha recounts past lives involving animal forms.

ekasāmantā.meaning_2: in the same neighbourhood; in the same vicinity
ekasāmantā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound adverb formed from 'eka' (same) and 'sāmantā' (in the neighbourhood, ablative of sāmanta). In the sentence 'vasāma ekasāmantā', it modifies the verb 'vasāma' (we live), indicating that the living occurs in the same neighbourhood as the subject or another party, corresponding to the English translation 'lived in the same neighborhood'.

abhinivissatha.meaning_2: clings to; attaches to; adheres to
abhinivissatha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'abhinivissatha' describes the action of firmly clinging or attaching oneself to what is good (kalyāṇa), emphasizing a resolute commitment or adherence to wholesome qualities.

upavassathuposathaṃ.meaning_2: observing the precepts on the uposatha day; observance of the sabbath day
upavassathuposathaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'upavassa' refers to the gerundial notion of observing precepts, 'atha' connects as 'and then', and 'uposatha' specifies the sabbath observance day. In context, it denotes the practice of keeping the precepts during the uposatha ceremony, translated as 'observe the sabbath day'.

gavesisuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, 'gavesisuṃ' indicates the action of searching for or seeking out something suitable, here specifically a 'dakkhiṇeyyaṃ' (one worthy of offerings, such as a monk or sacred site for making donations).
gavesisuṃ.translation_1: and sought out one worthy of offerings.

gavesayyuṃ.meaning_2: they might search; they might seek
gavesayyuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an optative 3rd plural form of gavesati ('to search, seek'), expressing possibility or mild command. The unusual spelling 'gavesayyuṃ' may reflect dialectal variation or scribal error for standard gaveseyyuṃ.

dakkhiṇanucchavaṃ.meaning_2: suitable for offerings; fitting for a gift; appropriate for one worthy of gifts
dakkhiṇanucchavaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, the compound describes a gift (dānaṃ) that is fitting or suitable (anucchavaṃ) for one worthy of offerings (dakkhiṇe), referring to a recipient like a monk or arahant. The accusative singular form agrees with dānaṃ.
dakkhiṇanucchavaṃ.translation_1: what sort of gift would suit one worthy of offerings:

yadihaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the provided sentences, 'yadihaṃ' introduces hypothetical conditional clauses where the speaker contemplates their own potential actions or states, such as finding a recipient or being upset. The form is a fixed combination functioning as a single indeclinable unit, common in Pāḷi for conditional 'if I' constructions.
yadihaṃ.translation_1: ‘If I were to find a worthy recipient,

sakamattānaṃ.meaning_2: to one's own self; to oneself
sakamattānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'dajjāhaṃ sakamattānaṃ' ('I shall give my own self'), sakamattānaṃ functions as the accusative object, emphasizing complete self-dedication or sacrifice of one's own being, with matta reinforcing the sense of 'one's own measure' or 'extent' of self.
sakamattānaṃ.translation_1: I shall give my own self:

brāhmaṇavaṇṇinā.meaning_2: in the guise of a brahmin; having the appearance of a brahmin
brāhmaṇavaṇṇinā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This instrumental singular adjective describes Sakka's disguise as a brahmin, combining 'brāhmaṇa' (priest of the Brahman caste) with 'vaṇṇī' (having the appearance of).
brāhmaṇavaṇṇinā.translation_1: Sakka in the guise of a brahmin

dānavīmaṃsanāya.meaning_2: investigation of giving; test of generosity
dānavīmaṃsanāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the dative sense to indicate purpose, as in 'for the investigation/testing of generosity'. The English translation reflects this contextual purpose: 'in order to test my generosity'.
dānavīmaṃsanāya.translation_1: in order to test my generosity.

ghāsahetu.meaning_2: for the sake of food; on account of fodder
ghāsahetu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'to me looking for food', ghāsahetu functions as an adverbial compound indicating the reason or purpose, equivalent to 'for food' or 'seeking fodder'.

mamantike.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'ghāsahetu mamantike' meaning 'to me looking for food', mamantike functions as a locative adverbial indicating proximity, 'near me' or 'in my vicinity', where the speaker is foraging for food.

sīlaguṇūpeto.meaning_2: endowed with the qualities of virtue; possessed of moral virtues
sīlaguṇūpeto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sīlaguṇūpeto functions as a predicate adjective in the sentence, describing the addressee as one equipped with virtuous qualities, aligning with the English translation 'You are furnished with virtue'. Here, sīla emphasizes ethical conduct, guṇa its positive attributes, and upeta the state of possession.

nānākaṭṭhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentences, 'nānākaṭṭhe' is the locative singular form of the compound 'nānākaṭṭha', meaning 'in/among different sticks', used with the verbs 'samānaya' and 'samānayi' to indicate the action of gathering performed in or among various sticks.

pacissamattānaṃ.construction: pac + i + ssa + m + att + ānaṃ
pacissamattānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi form of the future 'pacissāmi' (I shall cook) combined with 'attānaṃ' (myself) in the accusative, functioning as a reflexive object in the sentence.

haṭṭhamano.grammar: adj, in comps, from haṭṭha + mana
haṭṭhamano.meaning_1: having a joyful mind; elated; happy
haṭṭhamano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, haṭṭhamano describes the speaker's joyful state while saying 'sādhū', translated as 'happily'.

aṅgāragabbhakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, the compound functions as the direct object of katvā ('having made' or 'placed'), indicating the location where the ember is placed, likely a small pit or hollow for containing glowing coals in a ritual or practical context.
aṅgāragabbhakaṃ.translation_1: he placed an ember in the recess.

phoṭetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The absolutive form phoṭetvā indicates the action of shaking or dusting off the limbs, as seen in the context of shaking dusty limbs before proceeding to the gate.

rajagate.grammar: pp of gacchati, in comp with rajas
rajagate.meaning_2: gone with dust; dusty; covered in dust
rajagate.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'rajagate' is the locative singular of 'rajagata', modifying 'gatte' (locative plural of 'gata', limbs), indicating the limbs are in a dusty state, as if gone into dust, matching the English translation 'shaking my dusty limbs'.

mahākaṭṭhapuñjo.meaning_2: great pile of sticks; large heap of firewood
mahākaṭṭhapuñjo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears in nominative singular, functioning as the subject of the clause 'when the great pile of sticks...'. The compound combines 'mahā' (great) with 'kaṭṭhapuñja' (pile of sticks), emphasizing a large quantity of firewood, likely in a ritual or sacrificial context.
mahākaṭṭhapuñjo.translation_1: When the great pile of sticks

dhamadhamāyati.meaning_2: was burning and blazing; makes a throbbing sound; pulsating roar
dhamadhamāyati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dhamadhamāyati is an onomatopoeic present tense verb describing the intense, roaring sound of a fire burning, as in the context of āditto 'lit up, burning'. It combines the sound-imitating base dhamadhamā with the root √yat 'goes' to convey the action of the fire's blaze progressing with a throbbing roar.
