dhumadhumāyati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dhumadhumāyati appears to be a future tense derived from a compound stem dhumadhūma (intensive or reduplicated form of 'smoke'), indicating an action of producing or being filled with smoke. No specific contextual sentence is provided, so the meaning is inferred from the components.

dhamamāyati.meaning_2: is blowing towards; is sounding towards; is fanning towards
dhamamāyati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form dhamamāyati appears to be a prefixed present tense verb combining dhama- (from √dham, 'to blow, sound, fan') with ā- (towards) and the -ti ending; it likely indicates directed action such as blowing or fanning in a specific direction, though no sentences are provided for contextual confirmation.

taduppatitvā.meaning_2: having jumped up; having leapt up
taduppatitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'taduppatitvā papatiṃ' ('I leapt up and fell on it'), taduppatitvā functions as an absolutive indicating the prior action of leaping up onto the object (tad, 'it'), before the subsequent falling (papatiṃ). The literal sense 'having fallen up' reflects the etymology but contextually means jumping or leaping upward.
taduppatitvā.translation_1: I leapt up and fell on it,

jālasikhantare.meaning_2: midst of the flames; space between the flames
jālasikhantare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound jālasikhantare is a tatpuruṣa construction meaning 'in the midst/space between the flames of the net-like blaze'. Here, jāla (net-like) modifies sikhā (flames), and antare (in the midst) indicates location, fitting the context of being surrounded by fiery flames.
jālasikhantare.translation_1: in the midst of the fiery flames.

darathapariḷāhaṃ.meaning_2: distress and fever; stress and affliction; anxiety and burning
darathapariḷāhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound combining daratha (stress, anxiety) and pariḷāha (fever, affliction), used in the accusative singular to indicate the objects allayed by the action in the sentence.

hadayabandhanaṃ.meaning_2: heart with cords; heart bound with cords
hadayabandhanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'aṭṭhiṃ hadayabandhanaṃ' refers to bones and the heart secured or bound with cords, likely in a literal sense of binding or tying the heart organ with ropes or strings.

sasapaṇḍitacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound 'sasapaṇḍitacariya' meaning 'the conduct (or story) of the wise hare', likely referring to the Jātaka tale of the wise hare (Sasa Jātaka). In the context of 'sasapaṇḍitacariyaṃ dasamaṃ', it indicates the tenth chapter or section on this topic.

akittibrāhmaṇo.meaning_2: Brahman of infamy; Brahman in disrepute; disgraceful Brahman
akittibrāhmaṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound akittibrāhmaṇo is in the nominative singular form, used as the subject in the sentence. It describes a Brahman associated with infamy or disgrace, possibly in a derogatory or metaphorical sense contrasting with the ideal qualities of a true brāhmaṇa as an arahant or holy man.

kururājā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Nominative singular form of the compound 'kururājā', referring to the king of the Kuru country in the given context 'kururājā dhanañcayo', likely meaning 'the Kuru king, the accumulator of wealth' or similar.

dānavare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'yo te dānavare adā', dānavare is locative singular, indicating the sphere or context in which the giving (adā) occurs, likely meaning 'in the excellent gift' or 'in the generous offering'. The relative clause suggests 'he who gives to you in that excellent gift'.

dānaparikkhārā.meaning_2: requisites for giving; materials for charity; offerings
dānaparikkhārā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the phrase 'ete dānaparikkhārā', the word refers to these (ete) requisites or items intended for acts of giving or charity, likely in a monastic or ritual context where such materials are prepared.

sakattānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sakattānaṃ pariccajiṃ', sakattānaṃ is the genitive plural form of saka-atta ('one's own self'), functioning as the object of pariccajiṃ ('I abandoned'). Thus, it translates to 'of one's own selves' or 'of my own selves', indicating the abandonment of personal attachments or ego in a Buddhist context.

dānapāraminiddeso.meaning_2: detailed exposition of the perfection of giving
dānapāraminiddeso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the nominative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound used as a title for a section or chapter concluding with 'niṭṭhito' ('is finished'). It denotes the analytical description or treatise on the pāramī (perfection) of dāna (giving), one of the ten perfections in Buddhist literature.

hatthināgavaggo.meaning_2: Chapter on the Elephant; Elephant Chapter
hatthināgavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of the second chapter (dutiyo) in a Pāḷi text, likely the Dhammapada or similar, where 'hatthināga' refers to a mighty or royal elephant, and 'vaggo' indicates the chapter section. The structure follows standard compound naming for suttanta chapters.

mātuposakacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of supporting one's mother; behaviour of nurturing the mother
mātuposakacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'mātu' (genitive of 'mātar', mother) qualifies 'posaka' (supporter), and the combined 'mātuposaka' (supporting one's mother) is further qualified by 'cariyā' (conduct), resulting in a feminine abstract noun denoting the virtuous behaviour of maternal support, often in the context of filial duties in Buddhist ethics.

tavānucchavo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'tavānucchavo' functions as a vocative compound describing an elephant that is fitting or proper for the Great King, combining the genitive/dative form of the pronoun 'tava' (your/for you) with the adjective 'anucchavo' (suitable, proper).
tavānucchavo.translation_1: ‘Great King, an elephant that befits you

parikkhāyattho.meaning_2: need for investigation; need to dig a moat
parikkhāyattho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'parikkhāyattho' is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'parikkhā' refers to 'moat' (lit. something dug around), and 'attho' means 'need'. The phrase 'na tassa parikkhāyattho' idiomatically conveys that there is no need to take defensive measures against him, as he is harmless or trustworthy, equating to 'no need to dig a moat around him'.
parikkhāyattho.translation_1: No need to dig a moat around him,

āḷakakāsuyā.meaning_2: tethering to a post in a pit
āḷakakāsuyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context of prohibiting the act of tethering an animal to a post driven into a pit, as in the Vinaya rule against cruel treatment.
āḷakakāsuyā.translation_1: nor tether him to a post in a pit.

idhehiti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'sayameva idhehi’ti' meaning 'he will come here by himself', the form idhehi appears to be a quotative or narrative imperative, conveying the idea of coming here independently, as rendered in the future tense in English.
idhehiti.translation_1: he will come here by himself.’

tuṭṭhamānaso.meaning_2: having a pleased mind; elated; satisfied in heart
tuṭṭhamānaso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, tuṭṭhamānaso describes the king as elated or with a satisfied mind, functioning as a nominative singular masculine adjective in compound form agreeing with rājā.

chekācariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound chekācariyaṃ combines 'cheka' (clever; skilful) with 'ācariya' (teacher; trainer), indicating a skilful or expert teacher, as used in the sentence to describe a well-trained tutor.

padumassare.grammar: nt, loc sg of comp paduma + sara
padumassare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form padumassare is the locative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound padumassara, meaning 'lotus pond' or 'pond of lotuses', used to indicate location in the sentence 'he saw me in a lotus pond'. The sandhi change from -a + -a to -ā is adjusted in the compound form.
padumassare.translation_1: he saw me in a lotus pond,

bhisamūlaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form bhisamūlaṃ is the neuter nominative or accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound, combining bhisa (lotus stalk) and mūla (root), referring to the edible root portion of the lotus plant, a delicacy in ancient Indian cuisine.

yāpanatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of sustenance; for the purpose of upkeep; for the benefit of support
yāpanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'to feed my mother', yāpanatthāya indicates the purpose of providing sustenance or support, specifically for the mother's upkeep, combining the abstract noun yāpana (sustenance) with attha in its dative sense of 'for the sake of'.

sīlaguṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, sīlaguṇaṃ refers to the quality of moral virtue or ethical conduct being discerned, aligning with the primary senses of sīla (ethical conduct) and guṇa (virtue).

patvāna.meaning_2: having flown; having reached by flying
patvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form patvāna is the absolutive of the verb patati (to fly), with paṭi- prefix, indicating an action completed prior to the main verb in the sentence.

sarīrānugataṃ.meaning_2: gone along with the body; accompanying the body; natural to the body
sarīrānugataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, sarīrānugataṃ balaṃ refers to the inherent or natural strength that accompanies the body, as opposed to supernatural or mental strength.
sarīrānugataṃ.translation_1: the natural strength of my body,

samasādisaṃ.meaning_2: similar; like; of the same kind
samasādisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'balena samasādisaṃ' translated as 'of the elephants of today', it likely functions as a modifier indicating similarity to contemporary elephants, possibly in a comparative sense within the sentence structure.

sīlarakkhāya.meaning_2: for the sake of guarding ethics; for the sake of protecting moral integrity
sīlarakkhāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used in the context to express purpose, as in 'for the sake of guarding my ethics,' indicating motivation related to preserving one's moral conduct.
sīlarakkhāya.translation_1: Nevertheless, for the sake of guarding my ethics,
sīlarakkhāya.translation_2: For the sake of protecting ethics,

sīlapāramipūriyā.meaning_2: fulfilling the perfection of ethics; being complete in the highest state of morality
sīlapāramipūriyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sīlapāramipūriyā is the instrumental singular of the compound adjective sīlapāramipūrī, used here to indicate the manner of fulfilling the perfection of ethics, as in 'by fulfilling my perfection of ethics'.
sīlapāramipūriyā.translation_1: and fulfilling my perfection of ethics,
sīlapāramipūriyā.translation_2: and fulfilling my perfection of ethics,

mamāḷake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'pakkhipantaṃ mamāḷake', 'mamāḷake' is the locative singular of 'mālāka', meaning 'in the cage'. The prefix 'ma-' (my) combines with 'mālāka' (cage), forming a possessive construction equivalent to 'my cage', indicating the place where the speaker is being caged.

sīlakhaṇḍabhayā.meaning_2: fear of breaking ethics; fear of violating precepts; dread of corrupting moral integrity
sīlakhaṇḍabhayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound noun functions as an instrumental form meaning 'out of fear of breaking one's ethics' in the given contexts, where it explains the motivation for abstaining from an action to preserve moral precepts.
sīlakhaṇḍabhayā.translation_1: for fear of violating my ethics.”
sīlakhaṇḍabhayā.translation_2: for fear of breaking my ethics.

mātuposakacariyaṃ.meaning_2: supporting one's mother; conduct in supporting one's mother
mātuposakacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular of the compound noun, listed as the first item in a series, likely in a Vinaya context of duties or precepts.

bhūridattacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of abundant giving; way of life characterized by extensive generosity
bhūridattacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where 'bhūri' (abundant) modifies 'datta' (given), and the whole qualifies 'cariyā' (conduct), referring to a lifestyle of generous giving, common in Buddhist contexts as one of the perfections (pāramī).

bhūridatto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Bhūridatto is a proper name of a nāga king, appearing in the Bhūridatta Jātaka. Here it functions as a nominative subject, described as possessing great psychic power (mahiddhiko). The compound likely interprets as 'abundantly given' or 'greatly endowed', though used as a specific name.
bhūridatto.translation_1: Bhūridatta, a dragon of great psychic power,

devalokamagañchahaṃ.meaning_2: I went to a heavenly realm
devalokamagañchahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi compound formed in the context of a first-person aorist statement, where the speaker describes their own journey to a divine world, as per the English translation.
devalokamagañchahaṃ.translation_1: I went to a heavenly realm.

passitvāhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'tattha passitvāhaṃ deve', passitvā is the absolutive form indicating the action of seeing completed prior to the main verb, translating to 'having seen there, I [saw] gods', where 'deve' likely means 'gods' in accusative plural.

saggagamanatthāya.meaning_2: for the sake of going to heaven
saggagamanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This adverbial compound functions as a dative of purpose, indicating the goal of attaining heaven, as seen in the context 'for the sake of going to that heaven'.
saggagamanatthāya.translation_1: For the sake of going to that heaven,

yāpanamattakaṃ.meaning_2: just enough for sustenance; mere upkeep; sufficient for getting by
yāpanamattakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound yāpanamattakaṃ describes the minimal level of eating required for bodily sustenance, as seen in the context of bhutvā yāpanamattakaṃ, translated as 'eating enough to get by'. Here, yāpana provides the sense of maintenance, and mattaka emphasizes the 'mere' or 'simple' aspect, indicating sufficiency without excess.
yāpanamattakaṃ.translation_1: and eating enough to get by,

vammikamuddhani.meaning_2: atop the ant-hill; on the top of the termite mound
vammikamuddhani.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a locative singular of the compound vammikamuddhan, used adverbially to indicate the position 'atop a termite mound' in the context of the sentence, where the subject lies down there.
vammikamuddhani.translation_1: and lay down atop a termite mound, thinking:

nahāruaṭṭhikehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form used in context to refer to the physical components of sinews and bones, likely in a descriptive or anatomical sense within the text.

harātu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'harātu' is a polite imperative used by the Buddha to Ānanda, urging him to take the requisites that have already been given.
harātu.translation_1: they are already given, please take them.’
harātu.translation_2: they are already given, please take them.’

ālampāyano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'ālampāyano mamaggahi', ālampāyano is the subject in nominative singular, referring to the person named Ālampāyana who grabbed the speaker ('me'). The name is agentive, derived from a verb meaning 'to grab' or 'to seize', fitting the action described in the English translation.

ālambaṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ālambaṇo appears to be a nominative singular neuter, likely a variant or scribal error for ālambanaṃ, common in Pāḷi texts as a technical term in grammar and philosophy denoting a supporting object or foundation.

mamaggahi.meaning_2: came to me; approached me; lit. came grasping me
mamaggahi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this context, 'mamaggahi' is a compound of the pronoun 'mamaṃ' (me, accusative) and 'āgahi' (aorist of āgacchati, meaning 'came'), used idiomatically to express being seized or grabbed by someone named Ālampāyana, as per the English translation. The verb āgacchati literally means 'comes', but here it conveys approaching with intent to grasp, akin to the related gahi (from gaṇhāti, to take).

pakkhipitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'peḷāya pakkhipitvāna', the absolutive form indicates the action of throwing into the basket preceding the main action, translated as 'He threw me in a basket'.
pakkhipitvāna.translation_1: He threw me in a basket

ālampāyane.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Ālampāyana is the name of a person addressed in the sentence, functioning as the object of the verb 'na kuppāmi' ('I do not get angry'). The name appears to be a descriptive compound, possibly meaning 'one who causes a lamp to tremble' or similar, though used here as a proper noun.
ālampāyane.translation_1: I did not get upset with Ālampāyana,

sakajīvitapariccāgo.meaning_2: giving up of one's own life; self-sacrifice of life
sakajīvitapariccāgo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the subject in the sentence, expressing the act of sacrificing one's own life, as translated 'To give up my own life'.
sakajīvitapariccāgo.translation_1: To give up my own life

sīlavītikkamo.meaning_1: transgression of ethical principles; violation of virtue
sīlavītikkamo.meaning_2: transgression of ethical principles; violation of moral integrity
sīlavītikkamo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence, 'sīlavītikkamo mayhaṃ' indicates a personal transgression of one's own ethical conduct, aligning with the English translation 'To transgress my ethical principles'. The compound combines 'sīla' (ethical conduct, virtue) with 'vītikkama' (transgression), emphasizing violation in a moral or disciplinary context, common in Vinaya texts.

pathavīuppatanaṃ.meaning_2: overturning of the earth; shaking the ground; upheaval of the world
pathavīuppatanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is an accusative singular form of a tatpuruṣa compound used as the object in the sentence, conveying a simile of profound disturbance or cataclysmic change, akin to the earth being turned upside down.

peḷaketi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, peḷaketi represents peḷake + iti, where peḷake is the locative singular form of peḷaka meaning 'in a basket', indicating location even when something is thrown into it.
peḷaketi.translation_1: even when thrown in a basket.”

bhūridattacariyaṃ.meaning_2: the second Bhūridatta story; the second Jātaka tale of Bhūridatta
bhūridattacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a compound noun used as the title of the second Jātaka tale in the Cariyāpiṭaka, referring to the conduct or story of Bhūridatta, a nāga king who was a previous birth of the Buddha. 'Bhūridatta' is a proper name meaning 'abundantly given' or 'generously offered', derived from bhūri (abundant) + datta (given).

campeyyanāgacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the noble person of Campā
campeyyanāgacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound noun describing the exemplary conduct or way of life of a noble person (arahant) associated with the city of Campā; 'nāga' here refers to an epithet for an arahant, suggesting a title or biographical reference in Pāli literature.

sīlabbatasamappito.meaning_2: furnished with precepts and vows; endowed with ethics and observances
sīlabbatasamappito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term describes someone equipped or provided with sīlabbata, referring to moral precepts and ritual observances, often in the context of ascetics or those attached to external practices without deeper insight, as implied by the English rendering.

rājadvāramhi.meaning_2: royal gate; gateway of the king
rājadvāramhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The locative form rājadvāramhi indicates location at the royal gate, where the performance took place as per the sentence context.
rājadvāramhi.translation_1: and he made me perform at the royal gate.

pītalohitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound pītalohitaṃ is a dvanda (coordinating) compound meaning 'yellow and red', used here in the neuter accusative singular to list colors alongside nīlaṃ (blue) in the phrase nīlaṃ vā pītalohitaṃ, translated as 'blue, yellow, or red'. It refers to the primary colors associated with the three main Buddhist sects or robes.

cittānuvattanto.meaning_2: conforming (to); following (the wish of); submitting to the intention
cittānuvattanto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, cittānuvattanto describes the act of yielding or conforming to another's wish or intention, combining 'citta' (mind, wish) with 'anuvattanta' (following, submitting), fitting the English translation 'I conformed to his wish'.

cintitasannibho.meaning_2: resembling a thought; taking the appearance of thought
cintitasannibho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective in the nominative singular masculine form, used to describe something that assumes or appears in the form of a thought, as per the contextual sentence 'taking the appearance of his thought.' The first member 'cintita' is the past participle of cinteti, and 'sannibha' means 'like' or 'resembling.'
cintitasannibho.translation_1: taking the appearance of his thought.

kareyyamudakaṃ.meaning_2: water to be made; water that could be produced
kareyyamudakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'thalaṃ kareyyamudakaṃ', the compound functions as the object of the implied verb, meaning 'I could make dry land into water' or 'I could turn the dry land to water'. The form kareyya is optative 3sg, but the compound is accusative singular neuter, indicating the potential object of action.
kareyyamudakaṃ.translation_1: I could turn dry land to water,

cittavasī.meaning_2: under the sway (of thoughts); controlled by (the mind)
cittavasī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the conditional context 'yadi cittavasī hessaṃ', the adjective describes a hypothetical state of being dominated or controlled by one's thoughts or mind, contrasting with mental freedom in Buddhist teachings.
cittavasī.translation_1: If I was under the sway of my thoughts,

campeyyanāgacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of the noble one of Campā; way of life of the elephant from Campā
campeyyanāgacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term appears in a list as 'tatiyaṃ' (third), likely the third in a series of conduct types or epithets. 'Nāga' here probably refers to a noble person or epithet of an arahant/Buddha associated with Campā, with 'cariya' indicating their exemplary conduct.

cūḷabodhicariyā.meaning_2: minor conduct of awakening; lesser way of enlightenment
cūḷabodhicariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where cūḷa modifies bodhicariyā, indicating a subordinate or introductory aspect of the conduct leading to enlightenment. Likely refers to a specific text or section in Pāli literature, such as the Cūḷabodhicariyā, paralleling other 'cūḷa' works.

cūḷabodhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'cūḷabodhi susīlavā' refers to a person named Cūḷabodhi who is very virtuous (susīlavā). The name is a compound where 'cūḷa' means 'lesser' or 'minor', and 'bodhi' refers to 'awakening' or a proper name element, likely distinguishing this figure from another Bodhi.

susīlavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentences, 'susīlavā' is used as a vocative form addressing Cūḷabodhi as 'the very virtuous one' and in the second as part of 'well educated and virtuous', emphasizing moral excellence.

kanakasannibhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'kanakasannibhā' describes the brahmin lady's skin as golden or golden-hued, using the compound where 'kanaka' means gold and 'sannibhā' means resembling or like.
kanakasannibhā.translation_1: a brahmin lady with golden skin,

chinnabandhū.meaning_2: cutting off family; without relatives; without clinging
chinnabandhū.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'nirālayā chinnabandhū', the compound describes a state of detachment, literally 'with family cut off', paralleling 'without clinging' in the English translation, emphasizing renunciation of familial bonds in a spiritual sense.

bārāṇasimupāgamuṃ.meaning_2: name of a city; modern Varanasi
bārāṇasimupāgamuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form bārāṇasimupāgamuṃ is a sandhi compound where bārāṇasi is the accusative singular of the feminine noun bārāṇasī, serving as the object of motion in the verbal action of approaching or arriving. In the context 'until we reached Varanasi,' it indicates the destination of the journey.

vasāmubho.meaning_2: we both stayed; we both resided
vasāmubho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form vasāmubho is a sandhi combination of the 1st person dual present indicative of vasati ('vasāma') and the enclitic pronoun 'ubho' ('both'), functioning as a compound pronoun-verb. In the contexts, it denotes the dual subject 'we both' performing the action of staying or residing in the specified location.
vasāmubho.translation_1: we both stayed in the royal park.
vasāmubho.translation_2: on a bank of the Ganges.

uyyānadassanaṃ.meaning_2: visiting the park; going to see the park
uyyānadassanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'uyyāna' (park) is the object of 'dassana' (seeing). In the context of the sentence, it functions as the object of 'gantvā' (having gone), indicating the purpose of going: to visit or see the park.

tuyhesā.grammar: pron, 2nd gen sg of tvaṃ + fem nom sg of eta
tuyhesā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence ‘tuyhesā kā kassa bhariyā’, tuyhesā functions as a fused pronoun meaning 'is this woman yours?' or 'whose woman is she?', combining the genitive 'tuyha' (your) with the nominative 'esā' (this she) to refer to the woman in question.
tuyhesā.translation_1: ‘Is she your wife? Or whose is she?’

ekasāsanī.meaning_2: one in beliefs; sharing the same teaching
ekasāsanī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentences, 'ekasāsanī' functions as an adjective describing shared unity in doctrine or belief, as in 'sharing the same teaching and belief' or 'one in beliefs'. It is a compound where 'sāsana' (teaching, doctrine) is feminized with the suffix -ī.
ekasāsanī.translation_1: We share the same teaching and belief.’

sārattagadhito.meaning_2: infatuated with; obsessed with; bound by infatuation
sārattagadhito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sārattagadhita combines two past participles to intensify the sense of deep emotional attachment, as seen in the context where it describes being infatuated with 'her' (tissā), conveying a state of being charmed and bound by affection.

gāhāpetvāna.meaning_2: having caused to seize; having had seized
gāhāpetvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'gāhāpetvāna ceṭake' indicates the action of having one's men seize her, where 'ceṭake' likely refers to the female being seized, and the absolutive form shows prior action leading to the main verb.
gāhāpetvāna.translation_1: he had his men seize her.

nippīḷayanto.meaning_2: to compel; to force; to press
nippīḷayanto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form nippīḷayanto is the present participle nominative masculine plural of nippīḷayati, used here to describe those compelling the woman (assumed feminine referent) by force, indicating a group action in the context of coercion.

nayantiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'nayantiyā' is the instrumental singular feminine form of the present participle, indicating the manner or agency of 'dragging away' (ākaḍḍhitvā), literally 'by leading' or 'while leading', though the overall action conveys forcible removal.

sīlabbatamanussariṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'sīlabbatamanussariṃ' describes the act of recollecting one's precepts and vows, likely in a moment of reflection or temptation.
sīlabbatamanussariṃ.translation_1: I remembered my precepts and vows,

vaḍḍhitūpari.meaning_2: to the point of growing; excessively (in growth)
vaḍḍhitūpari.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'nādāsiṃ vaḍḍhitūpari', the form is an adverbial construction indicating the extent or purpose of 'growing', negated by 'na' to mean 'I did not allow it to grow (to that point)'. The 'ū' functions as an infinitive marker combined with the postposition 'upari' for 'up to' or 'to the point of'.
vaḍḍhitūpari.translation_1: I did not allow it to grow.

tiṇhasattiyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, tiṇhasattiyā is the instrumental singular feminine of the compound tiṇhasatti, referring to 'with a sharp knife' held by the brahmin lady. The compound combines tiṇha (sharp, of a blade) with satti (weapon, here specifically a knife or dagger).
tiṇhasattiyā.translation_1: that brahmin lady with a sharp knife,

sīlānurakkhisanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, sīlānurakkhisan is the gerund form meaning 'guarding (my ethics)', explaining the reason for protecting moral conduct as per the English translation.
sīlānurakkhisanti.translation_1: that’s why I guarded my ethics.”

cūḷabodhicariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a compound noun referring to the 'Minor Conduct' (Cūḷacariyā), likely the fourth section or chapter in a text on Buddhist conduct or perfections, as indicated by 'catutthaṃ' (the fourth). The term 'bodhi' here probably means 'enlightenment', so the compound suggests 'conduct pertaining to minor enlightenment' or simply 'minor conduct' in a doctrinal context.

mahiṃsarājacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where mahiṃsa (buffalo) modifies rāja (king), and the resulting 'buffalo king' modifies cariyā (conduct). The form shows feminine nominative singular with sandhi resolution ofṃsa+rāja toṃsarāja.

pavaḍḍhakāyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pavaḍḍhakāyo is the nominative singular masculine of the compound adjective pavaḍḍhakāya, where pavaḍḍha ('grown up, strong') modifies kāya ('body'), resulting in 'having a large/strong body'. In the sentence, it describes someone as 'large in body and strong', with balavā providing the additional sense of overall strength.

bhīmadassano.meaning_2: big and scary to see; having a fearful appearance; dreadful in sight
bhīmadassano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound bhīmadassano combines 'bhīma' (fearful, dreadful) with 'dassana' (seeing, appearance), describing something that is fearsome or awe-inspiring to behold, as in the sentence 'mahanto bhīmadassano' meaning 'big and scary to see'.

giridugge.meaning_2: mountain difficult place; craggy hillside; rugged terrain
giridugge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'giridugge' refers to a rugged, difficult hillside or crag, complementing 'pabbhāre' (cave) as a remote or challenging location. The compound combines 'giri' (mountain) with 'dugga' (difficult place, impassable terrain), evoking a steep, rocky slope.
giridugge.translation_1: In a cave, a craggy hillside,

vanadugge.meaning_2: forest that is hard to travel; wooded difficult place
vanadugge.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a compound referring to a forest that is difficult to traverse, combining 'vana' (forest) with 'dugga' (difficult place or road). In Pāḷi texts, such compounds often describe challenging terrains in narratives or similes for obstacles.

hotettha.meaning_2: would there be?; might there be? (in this place)
hotettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'hotettha' is an adverbial contraction of 'hoti ettha', meaning 'there would be here' or 'there might be in this place'. In the contextual sentence, it introduces a hypothetical scenario: 'there’d be somewhere for buffalos', indicating a potential existence or provision in this location for the buffalos (mahiṃsānaṃ).

upagantvāna.meaning_2: having gone; having approached; having reached
upagantvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The absolutive form upagantvāna indicates the action of going to the place (taṃ ṭhānaṃ) completed prior to the main action in the sentence, translating to 'having gone there'.

kapimāgantvā.meaning_1: having come along as a monkey
kapimāgantvā.meaning_2: having approached in the form of a monkey; having arrived like a monkey
kapimāgantvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form kapimāgantvā is a compound absolutive combining 'kapi' (monkey) in accusative with 'āgantvā' (having come), indicating the manner of approach in the context of the sentence where a monkey arrives.

ohanetitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ohanatitaṃ is the accusative singular neuter of the past participle ohanatita, derived from the prefixed verb ohanati ('strikes down' or 'drags down'). In context, it likely refers to something that has been overwhelmed or engulfed, functioning as an object in the sentence.

idamabravi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a sandhi combination of 'idaṃ' (nt acc sg of ima, meaning 'this') and 'abravi' (3rd sg aor of brūti, meaning 'said'). In the context 'yakkho maṃ idamabravi', it functions as direct speech introducer: 'the spirit said this to me', where 'idaṃ' anticipates the content of the speech.

nāsehetaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'nāsehetaṃ' is the 3rd singular imperative form of the causative of nassati, used as a command to kill or destroy the vile and wicked thing referred to as 'chavaṃ pāpaṃ'.

kāhāmiṃ.meaning_2: in the verse; in the stanza
kāhāmiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Likely a locative form kāhāmiṃ meaning 'in the kāhā' where kāhā refers to a verse or stanza in Pāli texts, possibly a variant or dialectal form of gāthā.

mamevāyaṃ.meaning_2: this very one of mine; this one (referring to me)
mamevāyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a sandhi combination where 'mama' (genitive of 'ahaṃ', 'of me') + 'eva' (emphatic 'very, just') + 'ayaṃ' (nominative singular of 'ima', 'this') forms a compound pronoun emphasizing 'this one belonging to or associated with me'. In the sentence context, it refers to the subject thinking of the speaker as 'this one' in a possessive or referential sense.

aññepevaṃ.meaning_2: in the same way; similarly; likewise
aññepevaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'aññepevaṃ karissati', it indicates that the action 'karissati' (will do) will be performed in the same manner towards others, emphasizing reciprocity or similarity in treatment.
aññepevaṃ.translation_1: will do the same to others,

hīnamajjhimaukkaṭṭhe.meaning_2: inferior, middling, and superior cases; lit. low, medium, and high
hīnamajjhimaukkaṭṭhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound refers to the three grades or categories of offenses or situations in the Vinaya context, specifically in relation to forgiving disrespect, ranging from low/inferior to medium to high/superior, indicating varying degrees of severity or status.

mahiṃsarājacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter accusative singular form of a compound noun mahiṃsarājacariya, used as the object in the sentence. In context, it refers to the 'conduct of the buffalo king', likely the title of the fifth story or chapter in a collection of tales about exemplary behavior.

rururājacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ruru (deer) modifies rāja (king), and the combined 'deer king' modifies cariyā (conduct), likely referring to a narrative or exemplary behavior associated with a mythical deer king in Pāḷi literature.

sutattakanakasannibho.meaning_2: resembling well-heated gold; like blazing hot gold
sutattakanakasannibho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an inflected adjective in the nominative singular masculine, used to describe the deer king Ruru, implying a golden or radiant appearance like well-heated gold, fitting for a majestic animal in the narrative context.
sutattakanakasannibho.translation_1: the king of deer named Ruru,

rurunāma.meaning_2: deer (so) called; a kind of deer, namely
rurunāma.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'ruru' (a type of deer) is qualified by 'nāma' in its sense of 'called' or 'namely', indicating a specific kind of deer. Without context sentences, the precise usage is inferred from dictionary meanings; it likely functions as a descriptive noun in texts referring to animals.

paramasīlasamāhito.meaning_2: focused on the highest ethics; endowed with the utmost virtue and composure
paramasīlasamāhito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a state of being perfectly concentrated in the supreme moral conduct, aligning with the English translation 'focused on the highest ethics,' emphasizing ethical perfection and mental steadiness in a Buddhist context.

gaṅgākūle.meaning_2: bank of the Ganges; lovely bank of the Ganges
gaṅgākūle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound gaṅgākūle is the locative singular form, used in the provided sentences to indicate location 'on a (lovely) bank of the Ganges', with the adjective manorame in the first sentence adding the sense of 'lovely'.
gaṅgākūle.translation_1: on a lovely bank of the Ganges.
gaṅgākūle.translation_2: on a bank of the Ganges.

ṭhatvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'gaṅgāya tīre ṭhatvāna', the absolutive form ṭhatvāna indicates the action of standing completed prior to the main action, translated as 'I stood' on the Ganges bank, providing the temporal or circumstantial context for the standing.
ṭhatvāna.translation_1: I stood on the Ganges bank

pakkhandohaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pakkhandohaṃ is a sandhi combination of the 1st person singular aorist pakkhandi 'I jumped' and the pronoun ahaṃ 'I', resulting in the fused ending -o- from i + a. In context, it conveys the speaker's action of leaping into the great river.
pakkhandohaṃ.translation_1: I jumped in the great river!’

assatthakālamaññāya.meaning_2: knowing the right time for relief; having discerned the opportune moment for recovery
assatthakālamaññāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, the compound gerund describes the Buddha's discernment of the right moment when the patient had recovered from illness, allowing for appropriate action such as resuming discourse. 'Assattha' here functions as the past participle of assasati, indicating 'relieved' or 'recovered' in the sense of restored health, combined with 'kāla' for timing and 'aññāya' for knowing.
assatthakālamaññāya.translation_1: When I knew he had recovered,

dhanahetuko.meaning_2: motivated by wealth; for the sake of riches
dhanahetuko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'pucchito dhanahetuko', it functions adverbially to describe the reason for speaking, indicating the action was performed due to desire for money or wealth, aligning with the English translation 'for the sake of money he told when asked'.
dhanahetuko.translation_1: for the sake of money he told when asked.

pakappayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'usuṃ tassa pakappayi', the word describes the action of fitting or nocking an arrow to the bowstring, with an implied sense of deliberate preparation or intention, as suggested by the English translation 'thinking'.

tiṭṭhateso.meaning_2: let him be; let him stay; let him remain
tiṭṭhateso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this context, 'tiṭṭhateso' is an optative form of tiṭṭhati ('may he stand/stay') used imperatively to advise the king to leave the person alone, translated as 'Let him be'.

nārakkhiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentences, 'nārakkhiṃ mama jīvitaṃ' is an elliptical construction meaning 'I did not protect my life', where 'nārakkhiṃ' is the first person singular aorist of 'rakkhati' (to protect) negated by 'na', with 'jīvitaṃ' as the object. The form 'rakkhiṃ' indicates past action, and the context from sentence 2 clarifies the protective sense over the literal 'not my life' in sentences 0 and 1.

rururājacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where ruru (deer) modifies rāja (king), and the whole qualifies cariya (conduct), in accusative case due to the -ṃ ending. The term likely refers to a narrative or story in Buddhist literature about the conduct of a king who is a deer or a deer-like king.

mātaṅgacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of an elephant; elephant-like behavior
mātaṅgacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'mātaṅga' (elephant) with 'cariyā' (conduct), likely referring to the behavior or way of life exemplified by an elephant, possibly in a metaphorical or narrative context such as a jātaka tale.

uggatāpano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a descriptive compound in vocative singular form, agreeing with an implied or elided noun like 'bho' or 'samaṇa'. It describes an ascetic with matted hair (jaṭilo) who practices severe, scorching penances (uggatāpano), as per the contextual sentence.
uggatāpano.translation_1: a matted-hair ascetic of severe penance,

assamaddasa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'uddhaṃ me assamaddasa', 'assama' is the object of 'addasa' (saw), with genitive 'me' (my) indicating possession, and 'uddhaṃ' (upstream) as the location. Thus, it translates as 'my hermitage upstream'.

paribhāsetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, paribhāsetvā forms the gerund of paribhāsati, indicating the action of abusing and cursing completed before the main verb, translated as 'having abused and cursed'.
paribhāsetvā.translation_1: Then he abused and cursed me,

muddhaphālanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'abhisapi muddhaphālanaṃ' ('that my head would split in seven'), the term refers to the splitting or cracking of the head, used in an imprecatory curse implying a dire consequence.
muddhaphālanaṃ.translation_1: that my head would split in seven.

gopaye.meaning_2: protect; guard; take care of; preserve
gopaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'yadi sīlaṃ na gopaye', 'gopaye' functions as the first person singular imperative of 'gopeti', expressing a hypothetical action of protecting or upholding one's ethics (sīla). The negative 'na' indicates 'not taking care of', contrasting with the protective duty emphasized in Vinaya literature.
gopaye.translation_1: and if I were not taking care of my ethics,

oloketvānahaṃ.meaning_2: having looked; having observed; having noticed; having checked; lit. having looked down; then just with a glance
oloketvānahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'oloketvānahaṃ' appears to be a scribal error or sandhi variant for 'oloketvā ahaṃ', where 'n' is likely an erroneous insertion. In context, it conveys the action of looking performed prior to speaking, translated as 'then just with a glance'.

duṭṭhamānaso.meaning_2: angry and bitter-hearted; having a corrupted mind
duṭṭhamānaso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, duṭṭhamānaso describes a state of intense anger combined with bitterness or malice in the heart/mind, emphasizing emotional corruption.

mātaṅgacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term appears as the seventh item (sattamaṃ) in a likely list of conduct types or perfections, where mātaṅga refers to 'elephant' in its primary sense, denoting a specific mode of ethical conduct or practice symbolized by elephant-like qualities such as strength or patience.

dhammadevaputtacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of a divine youth (devaputta) in accordance with the doctrine
dhammadevaputtacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where dhamma qualifies devaputtacariyā, indicating the conduct or behavior of a devaputta that aligns with the Buddha's teaching (dhamma).

mahāpakkho.meaning_2: of great retinue; having a large following or party
mahāpakkho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, mahāpakkho describes someone with a great retinue, interpreting pakkha as 'party' or 'group of supporters', combined with mahā 'great' to indicate extensive following, while mahiddhiko refers to psychic power separately.
mahāpakkho.translation_1: of great retinue and psychic power,

dasakusalakammapathe.meaning_2: ten skillful courses of action; ten wholesome kinds of deeds
dasakusalakammapathe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is locative singular, used in the context of 'establishing the populace' likely referring to the establishment or cultivation of the ten wholesome deeds in society or among people.

samitto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Samitto is an instrumental form of the compound samitta ('with a friend'), functioning as an indeclinable adverbial phrase in the sentence, indicating accompaniment by friends and associates.

saparijjano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'samitto saparijjano', saparijjano functions as an instrumental singular compound modifying samitto, indicating accompaniment by associates or companions, parallel to 'with friends and associates'.

sopettha.meaning_2: also here; in this place too
sopettha.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The adverb 'sopettha' combines 'so' (that, also) with 'ettha' (here), indicating 'also here' or 'in this place too'. In the context of the sentence, it modifies the wandering on the earth, suggesting the action occurs in this world as well.

okkamanatthāya.meaning_2: for the purpose of entering; for the sake of descent
okkamanatthāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence 'maggā okkamanatthāya' (from the path, for the purpose of entering), the word indicates the instrumental purpose of descending or entering into something ominous, metaphorically linked to the looming great war in the English translation, suggesting a path leading to conflict or downfall.

mahāyuddho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'mahāyuddho upaṭṭhito', the word refers to a great battle that has arisen or is present, though the provided English translation appears unrelated to this context and may be erroneous.
mahāyuddho.translation_1: aiming to push the other off the road.

sahaparijanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'sahaparijanaṃ tassa' is the accusative form functioning adverbially with the verb, indicating the target of the potential action of reducing to dust: him together with his retinue.
sahaparijanaṃ.translation_1: I could have reduced him to dust,

rajabhūtaṃ.meaning_2: as a king; in the manner of a king
rajabhūtaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form rajabhūtaṃ is a tatpuruṣa compound adverbial accusative, meaning 'in the state of having become a king' or 'as a king'. In the sentence 'rajabhūtaṃ kareyyahaṃ', it functions adverbially modifying the verb kareyyahaṃ ('I would do/make'), indicating the manner of action as if one has become a king, i.e., with royal authority or in a kingly way. The English translation 'together with his companions' appears unrelated or erroneous, as it does not match the Pāḷi construction; perhaps a mistranslation of the full context.

kareyyahaṃ.meaning_1: I would make; I would do
kareyyahaṃ.meaning_2: I would become king; I would act as king
kareyyahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form kareyyahaṃ combines the potential optative kareyyāmi ('I would do/make') with the pronoun ahaṃ ('I'), functioning as an emphatic first-person potential. In the contextual sentence 'rajabhūtaṃ kareyyahaṃ', it expresses the speaker's intention or hypothetical action of becoming king (rajabhūtaṃ, 'kingship' or 'royal state'), contrasting with the provided English translation which appears erroneous.

nibbāpetvāna.meaning_2: to quell; to calm; to pacify
nibbāpetvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'nibbāpetvāna mānasaṃ', the absolutive form indicates the action of quelling completed prior to the main action, translating to 'having quelled my mind' or simply 'I quelled my mind' in the provided English rendering.

janenokkamitvā.grammar: abs of okkamati, sandhi with jana
janenokkamitvā.meaning_2: having gone off with people; having left with one's folk
janenokkamitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi compound where 'jana' (people, folk) in instrumental case combines with 'okkamitvā' (absolutive of ukkamati, having gone off). In the context of the sentence, it describes departing from the road together with companions, aligning with the English translation 'I left the road with my folk'.
janenokkamitvā.translation_1: I left the road with my folk,

dāsahaṃ.meaning_2: giving to a slave; offering to a servant
dāsahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'pathaṃ pāpassa dāsahaṃ' translated as 'giving it to the wicked one', 'dāsahaṃ' functions as a compound indicating the recipient of the giving, where 'dāsa' refers to a slave or servant, and 'haṃ' is the neuter accusative of 'aha' meaning 'day'. However, the translation suggests 'pāpassa' (to the wicked one) modifies the recipient, possibly implying the slave is wicked. The form 'dāsahaṃ' is accusative neuter, serving as the object of 'giving'.
dāsahaṃ.translation_1: giving it to the wicked one.

pāpayakkhassa.meaning_2: wicked spirit; evil yakkha; malevolent supernatural being
pāpayakkhassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, pāpayakkhassa (genitive singular) refers to 'of that wicked spirit,' portraying the yakkha as malevolent or evil, consistent with the protective or malevolent nature of yakkhas in Pāḷi texts.

dhammadevaputtacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of the son of Dhamma; behavior of the deity born of the doctrine
dhammadevaputtacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the eighth item in a list, likely referring to a specific conduct or story involving a deity associated with the Dhamma, as in the Cariyāpiṭaka context where devaputtas represent bodhisatta perfections.

alīnasattucariyā.meaning_2: conduct of an active enemy; behavior of an alert adversary
alīnasattucariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where 'alīna' (active, alert) modifies 'sattu' (enemy), and the whole qualifies 'cariyā' (conduct). It likely describes a way of behaving that is actively adversarial or vigilant against enemies, possibly in a monastic or ethical context emphasizing alertness.

pañcālaraṭṭhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of the compound 'pañcālaraṭṭha', meaning 'in the kingdom of Pañcāla', as indicated by the context of the sentence describing a location in the fine city within that kingdom.
pañcālaraṭṭhe.translation_1: “In the fine city of kingdom of Pañcāla,

kampilāyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Kampilā is a place name, likely referring to a town or region in ancient India, used here in the locative case indicating location.

kappilāyaṃ.meaning_2: to the forming; to the fashioning; to the developing
kappilāyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form kappilāyaṃ is the dative singular of a neuter noun kappilāya derived from the adjective kappī 'forming, fashioning'; the related dictionary entry lāyi is unrelated and appears to be a parsing error.

jayaddiso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Proper name of a king, used in nominative case in both sentences to identify the subject. In the second sentence, 'atrajo ca jayaddiso' likely means 'and Jayaddisa the enemy' or 'and Jayaddisa the foe', with 'atrajo' as an adjective meaning 'hostile' or 'enemy'.

sīlaguṇamupāgato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sīlaguṇamupāgato functions as a past participle describing a state of having attained or being endowed with the qualities of ethical conduct (sīla) and virtue (guṇa), as per the contextual English translation indicating a furnished or possessed state.

anurakkhaparijano.meaning_2: one who cares for the attendants; protector of the retinue
anurakkhaparijano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound functions as a bahuvrīhi, describing the speaker as 'he who always cares for the attendants' (sadā), based on the contextual sentence. Anurakkha is the nominal form of the present participle anurakkhanta, indicating ongoing protection.
anurakkhaparijano.translation_1: I always cared for the attendants.

pitumaggahesi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pitumaggahesi is a compound where piti (from pitar, 'father') in the accusative case is combined with aggahesi ('seized'), functioning as an accusative of respect. In the sentence 'so me pitumaggahesi,' it means 'he who seized my father,' with 'me' as the dative 'to me.' The prefix 'a-' in aggahesi intensifies the action of grasping.

bhakkhosi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence ‘bhakkhosi mama mā cali’, bhakkhosi functions as a contracted form of bhakkha asi, meaning 'you are (my) prey'. Here, bhakkha (from √bhakkh, meaning 'food' or 'prey') is a predicate nominative, and asi is the 2nd person singular present of atthi ('you are'), used to express possession in the sense of 'you are my prey', akin to English 'you are mine' constructions.

tasitavedhito.meaning_2: trembling with fear; quaking in terror
tasitavedhito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a karmadharaya compound where tasitavedhito functions as a past participle phrase emphasizing intense fear through trembling and quaking, as seen in the context of being scared and trembling with fear.
tasitavedhito.translation_1: he was scared and trembled with fear,

porisādakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form porisādakaṃ is the accusative singular masculine of the compound porisādaka, used as the object of disvāna ('when he saw') in the sentence. The compound combines porisa ('man') with ādaka ('eater'), literally 'man-eater', translated contextually as 'cannibal'.

sasatthahatthūpagataṃ.meaning_2: bearing weapons in hand; armed and ready; with weapons approached to the hand
sasatthahatthūpagataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a state of being equipped with weapons held in hand, fitting the contextual sense of 'perhaps if I have weapons in hand,' implying readiness or possession for action.
sasatthahatthūpagataṃ.translation_1: Perhaps if I have weapons in hand

parittāsaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'were I to frighten him', parittāsaṃ functions as an indeclinable noun in composition, describing the action of causing fright, derived from paritta (emptied, made little/small) combined with āsa (shooting/hurling, extended to causing fear or agitation).

byāhariṃ.meaning_2: to speak; to say; to utter
byāhariṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'tassa dessaṃ na byāhariṃ', the negative aorist form denies any utterance of hateful words (dessaṃ) directed at him (tassa), conveying 'I said nothing hateful to him'.
byāhariṃ.translation_1: I said nothing hateful to him.

hitavādī.meaning_2: one who speaks beneficially; well-wisher; advisor for welfare
hitavādī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'mettacitto hitavādī', the compound describes a mind that is loving and one that speaks for the benefit or welfare of others, emphasizing compassionate and helpful speech.

ujjālehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence ‘ujjālehi mahāaggiṃ’, ujjālehi is instrumental plural, meaning 'with bright [flames]' or 'with shining [fires]', modifying the fire to be kindled; the provided dictionary entries for ujja and ala are unrelated to this form, which derives from ud + √jal, meaning to burn or shine.

mahāaggiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence ‘ujjālehi mahāaggiṃ’, the word is the accusative singular of a compound adjective-noun, meaning 'a great fire' as the object of the imperative 'kindle'.

pakkakālamaññāya.meaning_2: knowing the right time for ripening; knowing the appropriate occasion for maturity; knowing the time when cooked
pakkakālamaññāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'tvaṃ pakkakālamaññāya' ('When you know I am cooked'), the compound implies knowing the right moment when the speaker is 'cooked' or ready/matured, using 'pakka' in the sense of cooked or ripened, combined with time-understanding.
pakkakālamaññāya.translation_1: When you know I am cooked,

supakkakālamaññāya.meaning_2: knowing the right time thoroughly; understanding the time well
supakkakālamaññāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'supakka' (thoroughly ripe/mature) modifying 'kālamaññāya' (knowing the time), implying a nuanced sense of timely maturity or ripeness in understanding. No specific sentence context provided, so interpretation is based on literal composition.

pāṇātipātikanti.meaning_2: who kills living beings; who destroys life; murderous; attacking living creatures
pāṇātipātikanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence 'sadā pāṇātipātikan”ti', the form is instrumental singular masculine 'pāṇātipātikena', meaning 'by one who kills living beings', referring to someone characterized by constant attacks on living creatures as translated in the English.

alīnasattucariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of one who is alert towards the enemy; vigilant behavior against adversaries
alīnasattucariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term appears as the ninth item in a list (navamaṃ), likely denoting a quality or mode of conduct in a doctrinal or ethical context, emphasizing alertness and opposition to enemies, possibly metaphorical for spiritual vigilance.

saṅkhapālacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the conch shell guardian; behavior of the conch protector
saṅkhapālacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound saṅkha-pāla-cariyā, where saṅkha refers to the conch shell (primary meaning), pāla is the protector of it, and cariyā is the conduct or way of life. Likely the title of a specific jātaka story involving a nāga king named Saṅkhapāla who protects conch shells or is associated with them.

saṅkhapālo.meaning_2: name of a dragon king; conch-protector
saṅkhapālo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Saṅkhapāla is a nāga (dragon) king residing in the Himavat, known for his great psychic powers (mahiddhiko) and for protecting the Buddha from harm during meditation. The name is a compound where 'saṅkha' (conch shell) likely refers to his emblem or attribute, and 'pāla' means protector.
saṅkhapālo.translation_1: Saṅkhapāla, a dragon of great psychic power,

uragādhibhū.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'dvijivho uragādhibhū', the term describes a being as 'two-tongued, lord of serpents', likely referring to a mythical serpent king like Vāsuki or Takṣaka, emphasizing dominion over snakes.

catuppathe.meaning_2: at a crossroad; at a four-way intersection
catuppathe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound catuppathe is the locative singular form, used in the context to indicate location 'at a crossroad on a highway'. Here, uppatha likely means a diverging path or intersection, combined with catu 'four' to specify a four-way crossroad, fitting the English translation.
catuppathe.translation_1: At a crossroad on a highway

nānājanasamākule.meaning_2: crowded with many people; filled with various persons
nānājanasamākule.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a location crowded with diverse crowds of people, as per the contextual English translation.

vāsamakappayiṃ.meaning_2: prepared a dwelling; arranged a residence; made a home
vāsamakappayiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a first person singular aorist of the causative kappayati 'to make suitable', combined with vāsa 'dwelling'. In context, it means the speaker arranged or made a home in that place.

daṇḍamuggarapāṇino.meaning_2: with sticks and hammers in their hands
daṇḍamuggarapāṇino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound describing beings holding sticks (daṇḍa) and hammers (muggara) in their hands (pāṇi). The ending -no is the instrumental plural, indicating possession or accompaniment as per the context.
daṇḍamuggarapāṇino.translation_1: with sticks and hammers in their hands.

āropayitvāna.meaning_2: having caused to mount; having fastened; having tied
āropayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'kāje āropayitvāna', it means 'having fastened (me) to a pole', indicating an action of tying or securing to a physical object like a post.
āropayitvāna.translation_1: and fastened me to a pole,

sakānanaṃ.meaning_2: with its forests; with one's own woods
sakānanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular neuter compound, denoting accompaniment by one's own forests, as in the context of a place with its forests and mountains.

sapabbataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental compound in neuter accusative singular, used adjectivally to describe 'sakānanaṃ' (its forests), meaning 'with its forests and mountains' in the context of a place possessing both features.

nāsāvātena.meaning_2: with a blast from the nose; with nasal wind
nāsāvātena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the compound nāsavāta, referring to a forceful blast or wind expelled from the nose, as in the context of threatening to burn something with such a blast.
nāsāvātena.translation_1: I could have burnt it up with a blast from my nose.

jhāpaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, jhāpaye metaphorically conveys the ability to incinerate something forcefully, likened to a blast from the nose, emphasizing power or threat.
jhāpaye.translation_1: I could have burnt it up with a blast from my nose.

saṅkhapālacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of the tenth chapter in the Cariyāpiṭaka, referring to the conduct or story of the nāga king Saṅkhapāla, who practiced generosity and patience in a previous life.

parirakkhitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'jīvitaṃ parirakkhitvā', the absolutive form indicates the action of protecting one's life as a preliminary or concomitant condition to the main action implied in the larger sentence.

anurakkhisaṃ.meaning_2: I will protect; I will guard
anurakkhisaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'sīlāni anurakkhisaṃ', the form is a first-person future indicative, expressing the speaker's intention to protect or observe the precepts (sīlāni). The English translation is left blank, but contextually it means 'I will protect the precepts'.

saṅkhapālassa.meaning_2: conch-protector; Nāga king whose name means 'conch-protector'
saṅkhapālassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'saṅkhapālassa me sato' ('remembering Saṅkhapāla'), this is the genitive singular of the name of a Nāga king featured in the Saṅkhapāla Jātaka and other texts, where 'saṅkha' refers to the conch shell and 'pāla' to protector, likely alluding to the Nāga's protective role or shell-like hood.

sīlapāraminiddeso.meaning_2: analytical description of the perfection of morality; detailed exposition on the highest state of ethical conduct
sīlapāraminiddeso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sīlapāraminiddeso is the nominative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound, used here to indicate the completion of the section on the perfection of morality in the text, as per the sentence 'sīlapāraminiddeso niṭṭhito' meaning 'The exposition on the perfection of morality is finished.'

yudhañjayavaggo.meaning_2: conqueror in battle; victorious in fight
yudhañjayavaggo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the title of the third chapter in a Pāḷi text, likely referring to a victor or conqueror in battle, as in epic or sutta contexts where such names denote prowess in combat.

yudhañjayacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the conqueror in battle; warrior's way of behaving
yudhañjayacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'yudhañjaya' (battle-conqueror, i.e., warrior or victor in combat) serves as the qualifier for 'cariyā' (conduct). It likely refers to the behavior or exploits of a heroic figure in battle contexts, such as in epic or Jātaka literature.

yudhañjayo.meaning_2: victor in battle; conqueror in fight; of infinite fame
yudhañjayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound yudhañjayo is a tatpuruṣa, where yudha ('battle') qualifies jaya ('victory'), denoting 'victorious in battle'. In the context 'rājaputto yudhañjayo' (prince Yudhañjaya) and 'yudhañjayo somanasso' (Yudhañjaya delighted), it functions as a proper name for the prince, interpreted as 'of infinite fame' due to the renowned warrior connotation in ancient Indian nomenclature.

taññevādhipatiṃ.meaning_2: that very thing as the chief; that very one as the supreme authority; that alone as the primary matter
taññevādhipatiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound where ādhipati is the head noun modified by the genitive-equivalent taṃ eva ('of that very one'). In the context, it denotes treating that particular matter or authority as the foremost or supreme, as indicated by the English translation emphasizing prime importance.
taññevādhipatiṃ.translation_1: Taking that to be of prime importance,

saṃvegamanubrūhayiṃ.meaning_2: I fostered; I nurtured; I developed; I cultivated; I increased
saṃvegamanubrūhayiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is the first person singular aorist of anubrūhayati, indicating the speaker's action of fostering saṃvega (sense of urgency) in the context of the sentence 'I fostered that urgency.'

pabbajjamanuyācahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'pabbajjamanuyācahaṃ' is an inflected form where 'pabbajjaṃ' (accusative singular of pabbajjā) serves as the object of 'anuyācahaṃ' (I begged), meaning 'I begged for the going forth' or 'begged permission to ordain'. The phrase indicates requesting monastic ordination.
pabbajjamanuyācahaṃ.translation_1: and begged permission to go forth.

sanegamā.meaning_2: along with the citizens of town and country
sanegamā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of the compound 'sanegama', meaning 'together with town-dwellers', referring to citizens from urban areas in the context of the sentence.
sanegamā.translation_1: along with the citizens of town and country, they asked,

saraṭṭhakā.meaning_2: women of the town and country; female citizens of urban and rural areas
saraṭṭhakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'saraṭṭhakā' is a feminine form parallel to the masculine 'saraṭṭhakā' in the sentence, referring to the female counterparts among the citizens of town (sara) and country (aṭṭhaka, interpreted here as rural or village dwellers). This fits the context of people from both urban and rural areas asking together.
saraṭṭhakā.translation_1: along with the citizens of town and country, they asked,

sarājake.meaning_2: with the king; accompanied by the king
sarājake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sarājake is the locative singular of the compound sārājaka 'with a/the king', used here to denote accompaniment. The English translation 'The King and the Queens' suggests a collective reference, with sahorodhe providing the queens, and sarājake indicating the king in the same locative context.

sahorodhe.meaning_2: the king and the queens; the king together with his consorts
sahorodhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound saha + orodha (harem) refers to the king and his queens collectively, as indicated by the English translation 'The King and the Queens'. The form sahorodhe is locative singular, denoting location or association in context.

sanegame.meaning_2: with the citizens of town and country
sanegame.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an instrumental singular form of the compound 'sanegama', meaning 'town and country' or 'urban and rural'. 'Sa' is a prefix for 'with' (from saha), and 'negama' derives from 'nigama' (town), with 'ne-' indicating urban. In context, it denotes association with people from both urban and rural areas.
sanegame.translation_1: with the citizens of town and country,

saraṭṭhake.meaning_2: citizen of town and country; inhabitant of the country; townsman and countryman
saraṭṭhake.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound saraṭṭhaka is a dvanda or tatpuruṣa combining 'sara' (town or city) and 'aṭṭha' (country or realm), with -ka suffix indicating inhabitant. In the contexts, it denotes the general populace of urban and rural areas, used with locative case to indicate 'with the citizens'.
saraṭṭhake.translation_1: with the citizens of town and country,
saraṭṭhake.translation_2: with the military and the citizens—

ñātiparijanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an accusative singular form of a compound noun used in the context to denote 'family, retinue, and fame' as objects of possession or achievement.

yudhañjayacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of the conqueror in battle; heroic conduct
yudhañjayacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term yudhañjayacariyaṃ is an accusative singular form of a compound noun used as the title of the first chapter ('paṭhamaṃ') in a text, likely referring to the heroic or victorious conduct in battle, fitting the context of a narrative or epic section.

somanassacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of happiness; behavior of joy; way of gladness
somanassacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where somanassa (happiness, joy) qualifies cariyā (conduct, behavior). It likely refers to a joyful or happy manner of conduct in a Buddhist context, possibly denoting ethical behavior accompanied by a positive mental state.

somanassoti.meaning_2: thus joy; with joy; lit. joy thus
somanassoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form somanassoti is a sandhi combination of the genitive singular somanassa ('of joy') and the quotative particle iti ('thus'), used adverbially to indicate 'with joy' or 'joyfully'. In the context of the sentence, it describes the renowned state or quality associated with Vissuta, implying she is known for her joyful disposition.

guṇasampanno.meaning_2: full of good qualities; endowed with virtues; possessing characteristics
guṇasampanno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, guṇasampanno describes a state of being ethical and replete with positive attributes, aligning with the past tense narration 'I was ethical, full of good qualities.' The compound combines guṇa (quality, virtue) with sampanna (endowed with, full of), emphasizing completeness in virtuous qualities.
guṇasampanno.translation_1: I was ethical, full of good qualities,

kalyāṇapaṭibhānavā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an inflected adjective in instrumental singular masculine or neuter, used to describe someone possessing both beautiful and ready speech, as per the contextual translation.

kuhakatāpaso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'ahosi kuhakatāpaso' meaning 'who was favored by the king', the compound describes someone who is a tāpasa (ascetic) but characterized by kuhaka (deceitful), implying a pseudo-ascetic favored despite fraudulent nature.
kuhakatāpaso.translation_1: who was favored by the king.

natthimassa.meaning_2: there is nothing of him; there is no good in him
natthimassa.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'natthimassa sataṃ dhammo', the phrase functions as a genitive construction emphasizing the absence of any good or wholesome quality (sataṃ dhammo) in the person referred to, aligning with the English translation 'There is no good in him'.

sāmaññāpagato.meaning_2: strayed from asceticism; gone away from monkhood
sāmaññāpagato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sāmaññāpagato is the masculine nominative singular of the past participle āpagata 'gone away' in compound with sāmaññā 'asceticism, monkhood'. In the context of the sentence 'sāmaññāpagato ayaṃ' meaning 'he has strayed from asceticism', it describes someone who has deviated from or abandoned the monastic life, often used in disciplinary contexts in the Vinaya.

hirīsukkadhammajahito.meaning_2: having left the bright qualities of conscience; having abandoned the positive characteristics of shame and moral sense
hirīsukkadhammajahito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'hirī' (conscience or shame) and 'sukkadhamma' (bright or good qualities) form the object of the past participle 'jahita' (abandoned). In the given context, it describes someone who has forsaken the virtuous traits associated with moral conscience, as per the English translation.
hirīsukkadhammajahito.translation_1: He has left the bright qualities of conscience

jīvitavuttikāraṇā.grammar: ind, adv, abl sg of jīvitavuttikāraṇa
jīvitavuttikāraṇā.meaning_2: for the sake of livelihood; for the purpose of making a living
jīvitavuttikāraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This adverbial form indicates purpose in the context of the sentence, translating to 'for the sake of making a living,' emphasizing the motivation behind an action related to livelihood.
jīvitavuttikāraṇā.translation_1: for the sake of making a living.’

nisedhetuṃ.meaning_2: to restrain; to prevent; to prohibit; to put an end to
nisedhetuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'nisedhetuṃ' functions as the purpose infinitive, indicating the intent 'to put an end to it' before proceeding to do so.
nisedhetuṃ.translation_1: Before going to put an end to it,

uggatāpanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'the matted-hair ascetic of severe penance', uggatāpanaṃ describes the type of austerity practiced by the jaṭila (matted-hair ascetic), with ugga intensifying the sense of tāpana as heating or burning self-mortification.
uggatāpanaṃ.translation_1: the matted-hair ascetic of severe penance.

gantvānupaṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'tamahaṃ gantvānupaṭṭhānaṃ', the form gantvānupaṭṭhānaṃ functions as a compound absolutive where gantvāna ('having gone') modifies upaṭṭhānaṃ ('to the serving' or 'for the purpose of serving'), conveying the action of going to perform service on him. The variant -tvāna instead of standard -tvā is attested in Pāḷi texts.
gantvānupaṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: I went then to serve him,

mānanissito.meaning_2: dependent on pride; relying on conceit
mānanissito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'kuhako mānanissito' ('that prideful charlatan'), the compound describes the charlatan as one who depends on or is supported by pride, emphasizing egotism as the basis of his deceitful nature.

pabbājayāmi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'pabbājayāmi' is used as a first-person singular imperative expressing the act of banishing or exiling someone from the realm (raṭṭha), often in a royal or authoritative decree.

nisedhayitvā.meaning_2: having forbidden; having prohibited; having put an end to
nisedhayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'nisedhayitvā paccantaṃ' means 'after putting an end to the border conflict,' where nisedhayitvā indicates the action of prohibiting or resolving the conflict at the border (paccantaṃ) has been completed prior to the main action.
nisedhayitvā.translation_1: After putting an end to the border conflict,

kuhakamabravi.meaning_2: the king said to the charlatan
kuhakamabravi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a sandhi form resulting from the fusion of the accusative singular 'kuhakam' (to the charlatan) and 'abravi' (said), forming a verbal phrase where the king addresses the deceiver.
kuhakamabravi.translation_1: the king said to the charlatan,
