nāsiyo.meaning_2: deserving death; deserving execution; not to be let live
nāsiyo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'kumāro yathā nāsiyo', 'nāsiyo' is the neuter nominative singular of the present participle 'nāsī' (not being/existing), used in an adverbial sense with 'yathā' to mean 'in the manner that he is deserving of execution', i.e., the prince's actions warrant the death penalty under Vinaya rules.

catukhaṇḍikaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, catukhaṇḍikaṃ is the direct object of the gerund katvāna, referring to dividing the corpse into four pieces, as indicated by the English translation 'Saw his corpse into four pieces!' This form is accusative singular neuter of the compound adjective catukhaṇḍikā, meaning 'consisting of four pieces'.
catukhaṇḍikaṃ.translation_1: Saw his corpse into four pieces!

jaṭilahīḷitā.meaning_2: dreadlocked ascetic scorned; ascetic who is despised
jaṭilahīḷitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound jaṭilahīḷitā functions as a masculine nominative singular adjective modifying 'gati' (fate), describing the shameful destiny of one who despises or shames a dreadlocked ascetic, as per the context.
jaṭilahīḷitā.translation_1: this is the fate of one who shames the ascetic.’

mātuaṅke.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular of a compound mātuaṅka 'mother's lap' or 'lap of the mother', derived from mātu (gen. sg. of mātar 'mother') + aṅka ('lap'). Used to indicate position or relation, e.g., sitting on the mother's lap.

evamavacaṃ.meaning_2: I said to them; I spoke to them
evamavacaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word 'evamavacaṃ' is a sandhi combination of 'evaṃ' (thus) and 'avacaṃ' (I said), but the focused word is 'avacaṃ'. In the context, it indicates the speaker addressing 'them' (tesaṃ), conveying a direct statement or speech.

rājakiriyāni.meaning_2: royal business; matter concerning the king
rājakiriyāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'rājakiriyāni atthi me’, the accusative plural form indicates 'issues/matters for the king', with rāja denoting 'royal' and kiriyāni adapted to fit the sense of urgent royal concerns.
rājakiriyāni.translation_1: I have an issue for the king!’

dassayiṃsu.meaning_2: showed; presented; exhibited; caused to see
dassayiṃsu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'dassayiṃsu' describes the action of presenting or showing the speaker to the king, fitting the causative sense of the root √dis meaning 'to see'.
dassayiṃsu.translation_1: They presented me to the king,

pāpasevino.meaning_2: follower of evil; associate with wickedness; practitioner of bad deeds
pāpasevino.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, pāpasevino refers to one who follows the wicked one (Māra) and engages in his evil ways, emphasizing habitual association with immorality.
pāpasevino.translation_1: follower of the wicked one and his wicked ways.

vasamānayiṃ.meaning_2: having brought under control; having brought under one's power or influence
vasamānayiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'mamañca vasamānayiṃ', the form vasamānayiṃ is the accusative singular masculine of vasamānayitvā functioning as an indeclinable gerund. The English translation 'and brought him under my influence' reflects the sense of bringing someone under control or subjection, with 'mama' indicating 'my' influence.
vasamānayiṃ.translation_1: and brought him under my influence.

mahārajjamadāsi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a sandhi compound where the dative singular 'mahārajjam' (great kingdom) is combined with the aorist 'adāsi' (gave/offered) from √dā, functioning as a finite verb form meaning 'offered the great kingdom' in the context of the sentence.

somanassacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of gladness; behavior characterized by joy; joyful conduct
somanassacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the neuter accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound somanassacariyā, functioning as the object of a verb like 'practices' or 'engages in'. In the sentence 'somanassacariyaṃ dutiyaṃ', it likely means 'joyful conduct (is the) second', referring to the second of a series of mental or ethical states, such as the second joy (pīti) in meditation or a list of positive mind states.

ayogharacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of one without house or home; wandering behavior
ayogharacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound ayogharacariyā combines 'ayo' (iron, but here likely a misinterpretation; actually from 'a-' privative + 'ghara' house) forming 'ayoghara' meaning homeless, with 'cariyā' meaning conduct, thus denoting the lifestyle or behavior of a homeless wanderer, typical in monastic contexts.

ayogharamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The locative singular 'ayogharamhi' is used in the sentence to indicate the place where the speaker grew up, translated as 'in an iron house'. This compound combines 'ayo' (iron, stem !ay) and 'ghara' (house, stem ghar), with the locative ending -mhi.
ayogharamhi.translation_1: I grew up in an iron house,
ayogharamhi.translation_2: I grew up in an iron house,

nāmenāsi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'nāmenāsi ayogharo', 'nāmenāsi' is the instrumental singular of 'nāma', functioning as a quasi-adverb meaning 'by name' or 'so', indicating the manner of naming. The construction 'nāmenā + asi' (with 'āsi' as a form of 'atthi') translates to 'so [you] were named Ayoghara', explaining the person's name.

ayogharo.meaning_2: one who has no house; houseless
ayogharo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The name 'Ayoghara' is formed as a descriptive compound meaning 'one without a house', indicating a state of homelessness or wandering, as reflected in the naming context of the sentence.

saṃpīḷe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentences, saṃpīḷe is the locative singular of saṃpīḷa, indicating place of confinement or rearing, as in being raised in a confined space.
saṃpīḷe.translation_1: as you’ve been raised in confinement.

patiposito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of saṃpīḷe patiposito, the prefix pati- ('back') combined with posita ('nourished') conveys being brought up or raised in a state of confinement (saṃpīḷe), as per the English translation.
patiposito.translation_1: as you’ve been raised in confinement.

saraṭṭhakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this context, saraṭṭhakaṃ refers to the combined group of inhabitants from rural (sara, possibly countryside or reed areas) and urban (aṭṭhaka, town) areas, to whom obeisance is offered. The English translation interprets it as citizens of country and town.
saraṭṭhakaṃ.translation_1: Having bowed to the citizens of country and town,

sanigamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound sanigamaṃ is an accusative singular form used as the object of the gerund saraṭṭhakaṃ, indicating the recipients of the bowing action in the context of the sentence.
sanigamaṃ.translation_1: Having bowed to the citizens of country and town,

vanditva.meaning_2: having worshipped; having paid homage; having saluted
vanditva.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'sajanaṃ vanditva khattiyaṃ', vanditvā indicates the action of worshipping or paying respect to the people (sajanaṃ) before addressing or approaching the king (khattiyaṃ), a common gerundial construction in Pāḷi denoting prior action.

hīnamukkaṭṭhamajjhimā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound adjective describes a tripartite classification, likely of qualities, statuses, or levels, as indicated by the English translation 'low, middle, or high'.

nirārakkhā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'nirārakkhā sake gehe' describes a situation where someone is unprotected even in their own home, emphasizing vulnerability.
nirārakkhā.translation_1: are unprotected in their own home,

sakañātibhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'vaḍḍhanti sakañātibhi', 'sakañātibhi' is the instrumental plural of the compound 'saka-ñāti', meaning 'with their own relatives' or 'with their families', explaining how they grew up in the context of familial support.
sakañātibhi.translation_1: in which they grew up with their families.

candasūriye.meaning_2: by sun or moon; by moon or sun
candasūriye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular neuter of the dvandva compound candasūriya 'sun and moon', used here in a context of dim or scarcely lit light, as in the translation 'scarcely lit by sun or moon'. The form appabhe indicates weak or faint illumination.
candasūriye.translation_1: scarcely lit by sun or moon.

pūtikuṇapasampuṇṇā.meaning_2: filled with rotting carcasses; full of decaying corpses
pūtikuṇapasampuṇṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This compound adjective describes something overflowing or replete with the foul imagery of putrefying bodies, emphasizing themes of decay and impurity in the context.

pakkhittayoghare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound pakkhittayoghare is a locative singular form used in the sentence 'puna pakkhittayoghare' meaning 'I was tossed in an iron house.' Here, pakkhitta is the past participle of pakkhipati (to throw into), ayo means iron, and ghara means house, collectively referring to a prison or iron cell where the speaker was thrown.
pakkhittayoghare.translation_1: I was tossed in an iron house.

paramadāruṇaṃ.meaning_2: most cruel; extremely terrible; appallingly dreadful
paramadāruṇaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'dukkhaṃ paramadāruṇaṃ', the compound describes suffering (dukkha) as the most intense and cruel form, emphasizing its supreme dreadfulness.

ukkaṇṭhitomhi.grammar: pr 1st sg of atthi, with pp ukkaṇṭhita as predicate adj
ukkaṇṭhitomhi.meaning_2: I am sick of; I am dissatisfied; I am annoyed
ukkaṇṭhitomhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'ukkaṇṭhitomhi kāyena', the form expresses the speaker's state of being fed up specifically with the body (kāyena in instrumental case), conveying dissatisfaction or annoyance with physical existence.
ukkaṇṭhitomhi.translation_1: I’m fed up with the body,

rajjenamhi.meaning_2: in kingship; in rulership; in sovereignty
rajjenamhi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'rajjenamhi anatthiko', 'rajjenamhi' is a locative construction equivalent to 'in kingship' (rajje + naṃ atthi, meaning 'there is not in kingship'), expressing the context where the speaker has no need or interest.
rajjenamhi.translation_1: I have no need for kingship.

maddiye.meaning_2: place where one is crushed; crushing ground
maddiye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'maddiye' is the locative singular of 'maddiyaṃ', meaning 'in the place where Death crushes', referring to a realm or state beyond death's destructive reach.
maddiye.translation_1: where Death will not crush me.’

ayogharacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of homelessness; behavior of a homeless person
ayogharacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term ayogharacariyaṃ is a compound used in Vinaya contexts to denote the third type of offense or rule related to the conduct of homelessness, emphasizing the monastic way of life without a house or home. The accusative form suggests it is the object in the sentence, likely 'the third [is] the conduct of homelessness'.

bhisacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of a physician; medical practice
bhisacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word appears to be a tatpuruṣa compound where 'bhisa' (shortened form of bhisaja, meaning physician) qualifies 'cariyā' (conduct or behavior). Thus, it denotes the conduct or practice associated with a physician, likely referring to medical profession or ethical behavior in healing.

puravaruttame.meaning_2: foremost excellent capital citadel; supreme fine fortress
puravaruttame.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the locative singular form, it denotes the location 'in the capital citadel of Kāsi', combining 'puravara' (excellent city/fortress) with 'uttama' (supreme), emphasizing its preeminence as the chief fortified urban center of the Kāsi kingdom.
puravaruttame.translation_1: in the capital citadel of Kāsi,

hirīsukkamupāgato.meaning_2: having attained a pure conscience; furnished with pure conscience
hirīsukkamupāgato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a past participle used predicatively, describing someone who has reached or is endowed with a state of pure conscience (hirī + sukka), as per the contextual translation 'furnishing with pure conscience'. The compound hirīsukkam- likely stems from hirī (conscience) + sukka (pure), with sandhi adjustment.

ekamānasā.meaning_2: with one mind; unanimous; having a single intention
ekamānasā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'sahāyā ekamānasā' ('my friends with one mind'), it describes friends united in purpose or agreement, emphasizing harmony of thought or intention.

gihīdhamme.meaning_2: the ways or duties of a householder; the dhammas pertaining to lay life
gihīdhamme.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the locative singular form gihīdhamme, this compound refers to the principles, duties, or methods (dhammā) by which a householder (gihī) can attain happiness (sukhāvahaṃ), as indicated by the contextual sentence.
gihīdhamme.translation_1: about the ways a householder can find happiness,

phālasamaṃ.meaning_2: evenly like a ploughshare; smooth as a blade
phālasamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form phālasamaṃ appears to be an adverbial compound, likely functioning as an indeclinable expression meaning 'evenly' or 'smoothly like a ploughshare,' evoking the level cut of a blade. No contextual sentences provided, but this interpretation aligns with poetic or descriptive usage in Pāḷi texts.

gihībhāvaṃ.meaning_2: householder's state; lay life; condition of a householder
gihībhāvaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, gihībhāvaṃ refers to the worldly condition of being a householder, which the speaker rejects in favor of renunciation.
gihībhāvaṃ.translation_1: ‘I wish not for the householder’s state,

pitumātu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form pitumātu is a sandhi compound combining 'pitar' (father, acc.sg.masc.) and 'mātu' (gen.sg.fem. of mātar, meaning 'of the mother'). It likely functions as a possessive or genitive construction referring to 'of father and mother' in context, common in Pāḷi for familial relations.

sāvayuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'pitu mātu ca sāvayuṃ', sāvayuṃ is the accusative plural form referring to 'relatives' or 'kinsmen', indicating that the action (telling) was directed towards the parents and other relatives.
sāvayuṃ.translation_1: they told my mother and father .

evamāhu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'mātāpitā evamāhu', it functions as a quotative marker indicating that the parents said the following words, often rendered in English as 'said this' to introduce reported speech.

amitadhanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, amitadhanaṃ is the accusative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as the object of chaḍḍayitvā 'having discarded', indicating the vast, uncountable treasures renounced.

chaḍḍayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, it describes the act of giving up or renouncing immense wealth, fitting the theme of detachment in Buddhist texts.

bhisacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form bhisacariyaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the compound bhisacariya, denoting the conduct or profession of a physician (bhisa). In the sentence 'bhisacariyaṃ catutthaṃ', it refers to the fourth topic or section in a Vinaya context, likely the rules or conduct pertaining to physicians.

soṇapaṇḍitacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the wise Soṇa; way of behaving of the learned Soṇa
soṇapaṇḍitacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound referring to the conduct or life story of Soṇa the Wise, likely alluding to the arahant monk Soṇa Kuṭikaṇṇa, known for his eloquence and wisdom, in the context of Buddhist biographical or ethical narratives.

kulavare.meaning_2: belonging to an excellent family; of the best household
kulavare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'tattha kulavare seṭṭhe', it describes the place of rebirth as one of the highest or most excellent family status, aligning with the English translation indicating a rebirth in a superior social position.

ajāyahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, ajāyahaṃ describes the speaker's birth in a fine, wealthy, and eminent family, emphasizing origin and social status.
ajāyahaṃ.translation_1: in a fine, wealthy, and eminent family.

tamotthaṭaṃ.meaning_2: smothered in darkness; enveloped by darkness
tamotthaṭaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'tamotthaṭaṃ' is an accusative singular neuter form used to describe the state of someone who had become blind, metaphorically indicating being overwhelmed or suffocated by darkness.
tamotthaṭaṃ.translation_1: had become blind, smothered in darkness.

tuttavegahataṃ.meaning_2: harshly pricked by a goad; struck with forceful stabbing
tuttavegahataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound functioning as an adverb in the instrumental sense with viya ('as if'), describing a sensation of being harshly pricked or goaded, combining the ideas of stabbing (tutta from tud), forceful impulse (vega from vij), and being struck (hata from han).
tuttavegahataṃ.translation_1: as if harshly pricked by a goad.

chandamācikkhiṃ.meaning_2: told of desire; informed of intention; expressed wish
chandamācikkhiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form chandamācikkhiṃ is a 1st person singular aorist of the compound verb chandam ācikkhati, meaning 'to declare one's desire' or 'to express intention'. In the sentence 'tesampi chandamācikkhiṃ', it translates as 'I told them of my desire', where chanda specifically refers to personal wish or intention in this context, fitting the English rendering.
chandamācikkhiṃ.translation_1: I told them of my desire, saying,

nāmāsi.meaning_2: called; named; by the name of; namely
nāmāsi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, 'nāmāsi' is a sandhi combination of 'nāma' + 'asi', where 'nāma' functions as an adverb meaning 'called' or 'named', specifying the name 'Nanda' and the attribute 'paṇḍito' (the astute).
nāmāsi.translation_1: who was named Nanda the astute,

soṇapaṇḍitacariyaṃ.meaning_2: the conduct of Soṇa the Wise; the way of behaving of Soṇa the Pandit
soṇapaṇḍitacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the fifth chapter or section in a text, likely the Cariyāpiṭaka or similar, describing the virtuous conduct of the monk Soṇa, who is characterized as a pandit (learned sage). The accusative form indicates it as the object, possibly 'the Soṇa-pandit-conduct (is the) fifth.' Soṇa here refers to the monk Soṇa Kuṭikaṇṇa, renowned for eloquence.

temiyacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of getting wet; wet behaviour; way of behaving that involves wetting
temiyacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a compound noun formed from the present participle 'temiya' (getting wet, from the passive of temati, based on √tim) and 'cariyā' (conduct, behaviour, from √car). It likely denotes a state or manner of conduct involving getting wet, possibly metaphorical in Buddhist texts for spiritual purification or immersion in practice. No sentences provided for contextual nuance.

temiyoti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'temiyoti vadanti maṃ', 'temiyoti' is the vocative form of the proper name Temiya, used as the object of 'vadanti' (they call), indicating that 'they called me Temiya'.

soḷasitthisahassānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound meaning 'sixteen thousand women', used in the genitive plural to refer to the sixteen thousand court women in the context of the sentence.
soḷasitthisahassānaṃ.translation_1: None of the sixteen thousand court women

ahamekako.meaning_2: I alone; I, the only one
ahamekako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ahamekako is a sandhi compound combining the pronoun ahaṃ ('I') with the adjective ekako ('alone, solitary'), used here in the nominative singular masculine to describe the speaker as the unique or only one in the context of birth, as in 'I was born, the only one.'
ahamekako.translation_1: I was born, the only one.

niddāyamāno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form niddāyamāno is the present participle masculine nominative singular of niddāyati, functioning as a predicate adjective describing the subject sleeping on the fine bed. The -māna ending indicates a durative or intensive aspect, often used for ongoing actions like sleeping.

sayanavare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'sayanavare' is the locative singular form of the compound 'sayanavara', describing the location of sleeping as 'on the fine bed', emphasizing its excellence or superior quality.

pabujjhitvānahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'pabujjhitvānahaṃ tadā' ('then having awoken, I...'), the absolutive form indicates the action of waking up prior to the main verb, emphasizing the sequence of events.

pubbasālohitā.meaning_2: former blood-relation; previous relative by blood
pubbasālohitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, pubbasālohitā functions as a feminine adjective in the nominative singular, describing a female who is a previous blood relative of the speaker.

yojayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'yojayi' means 'enjoined' or 'assigned', indicating that the speaker was directed or applied to three states or places (ṭhānesu).
yojayi.translation_1: and enjoined me to three states.

paṇḍiccayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence ‘mā paṇḍiccayaṃ vibhāvaya,’ the word paṇḍiccayaṃ (accusative singular) means 'intelligence' and is used in the imperative context of not displaying or showing it, implying a caution against overt cleverness or wisdom.

bālamato.meaning_2: as a fool; like a fool
bālamato.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'bālamato bhava sabbapāṇinaṃ', it functions as an adverbial ablative expressing manner, advising to behave in the manner of a fool towards all beings, possibly implying humility or unpretentiousness.
bālamato.translation_1: be as a fool to all creatures,

ocināyatu.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In this context, ocināyatu is used in the optative sense of an imperative to express a wish or curse that all people scorn or despise the subject, diverging from the literal meaning of gathering or collecting.

vuttāyahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is an absolutive construction combining the past participle 'vutta' (spoken) from √vac with the locative adverbial suffix -āya indicating 'upon having done' and the pronoun 'ahaṃ' (I). In the context, it functions as an adverbial phrase meaning 'after I had spoken' or 'when I had spoken', matching the English translation 'When she had spoken' adjusted for first-person usage.

atthakāmāsi.grammar: 2nd sg of atthi, modified by adj
atthakāmāsi.meaning_2: you are benevolent; you are sympathetic; you wish well
atthakāmāsi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the vocative address 'atthakāmāsi me amma', the adjective atthakāma is compounded with the verb atthi to form a predicate adjective in 2nd person singular, meaning 'you are one who desires benefit (for me)', aligning with the English 'You wish to help me, mom'.
atthakāmāsi.translation_1: You wish to help me, mom,

hitakāmāsi.meaning_2: you desire my welfare; you are well-wishing towards me
hitakāmāsi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form hitakāmāsi results from sandhi between the feminine vocative singular hitakāmā (addressing the goddess) and the 2nd person singular present asi ('you are'). In context, it vocatively affirms to the goddess that she is benevolent and desires the speaker's welfare.

gativivajjito.meaning_2: crippled; unable to walk; deprived of the power of movement
gativivajjito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a state of being deprived of gati in the sense of 'way of going' or 'gait', hence crippled or unable to walk, as per the contextual sentence.

senāpatipurohitā.meaning_2: generals and priests; military leaders and chief priests
senāpatipurohitā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a dvanda compound listing two categories of officials included in the group, translated as 'including the generals and priests' in the contextual sentence, referring to key military and religious figures.

tapociṇṇo.meaning_2: devoted to ascetic practice; fervently engaged in austerity; lit. one who has accomplished heat/austerity
tapociṇṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tapociṇṇo is an adjectival compound where tapo refers to ascetic practice or austerity (from √tap 'to burn'), and ciṇṇa is the past participle of carati meaning 'accomplished' or 'practised'. In the context of the sentence, it describes the Buddha's fervent dedication to asceticism for the sake of enlightenment, emphasizing the intense effort expended.
tapociṇṇo.translation_1: ‘The goal for which I lived fervently

rājaveṭhanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'veṭhetvā rājaveṭhanaṃ' meaning 'with my turban wrapped', rājaveṭhanaṃ refers to a royal or personal turban, functioning as the object of the gerund veṭhetvā (having wrapped), indicating the action of wrapping the turban around the head.

ravimaṇḍale.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, ravimaṇḍale is locative singular, meaning 'in the sun's orb' or 'when the sun's orb', indicating the time of sunrise.
ravimaṇḍale.translation_1: when the sun’s orb had risen,

vanamupāgami.meaning_2: went to; came to; approached; arrived at
vanamupāgami.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, vanamupāgami describes the charioteer (sārathī) approaching or arriving at the wood (vana), indicating physical movement to a location.
vanamupāgami.translation_1: until the charioteer came to a wood.

ekokāse.meaning_2: in one place; in the open; at a single spot
ekokāse.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, ekokāse functions adverbially in the locative case, indicating the location where the chariot is left, translated as 'in the open'. It is a compound of eka 'one' and okāsa 'space', meaning a single open space.
ekokāse.translation_1: Leaving the chariot in the open,

hatthamuccito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a compound past participle functioning as an adjective, describing the horse (sajjassaṃ) that has been released from the hand, likely referring to letting go of the reins or bridle in the context of the sentence.
hatthamuccito.translation_1: the bridled horse released from his hand,

hatthamuñcito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahuvrīhi compound where muñcito is the past participle of muñcati (to release), functioning nominally in the neuter. The form hatthamuñcito suggests an inflected form (likely nominative or accusative singular neuter) in a textual context, possibly describing something released by hand or with the hand.

adhiṭṭhitamadhiṭṭhānaṃ.meaning_2: basis of determination; foundation of resolve
adhiṭṭhitamadhiṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form appears to be a sandhi compound functioning as a neuter noun in accusative singular, likely 'adhiṭṭhitaṃ adhiṭṭhānaṃ' where the final -ṃ of adhiṭṭhitaṃ elides before the initial a- of adhiṭṭhānaṃ. In context, it conveys a foundational resolve or determined standpoint, possibly explaining the speaker's fear amid diverse circumstances, as a mental fixation providing stability.
adhiṭṭhitamadhiṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: I was afraid for the many different

vividhakāraṇā.grammar: ind, adv, abl sg of vividhakāraṇa
vividhakāraṇā.meaning_2: because of various reasons; for various causes
vividhakāraṇā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'tajjento vividhakāraṇā', it indicates the resolution or undertaking was due to multiple or assorted causes, explaining the motivation behind the action.

tamadhiṭṭhānaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'na bhindiṃ tamadhiṭṭhānaṃ', the word refers to a specific resolve or determination that the speaker did not break, aligning with the sense of adhiṭṭhāna as 'decisive resolution'.
tamadhiṭṭhānaṃ.translation_1: so I did not break that resolve,

vatamadhiṭṭhahiṃ.meaning_2: resolved on my vow; determined on the religious practice
vatamadhiṭṭhahiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a 1st person singular aorist with enclitic -hiṃ indicating 'on me' or emphatic 'I'. In context, it expresses the speaker's past resolution specifically on their vow or spiritual practice, aligning with the English translation 'I resolved on my vow'.
vatamadhiṭṭhahiṃ.translation_1: that is why I resolved on my vow.

temiyacariyaṃ.grammar: nt, in comps, from temiyati + cariyā
temiyacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of getting wet; behavior involving wetting
temiyacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'temiyacariyāṃ chaṭṭhaṃ', this appears to be the accusative singular of a compound noun naming the sixth (topic, rule, or section) related to the conduct or practice of 'getting wet', possibly referring to a specific monastic rule or case in the Vinaya involving wetting or purification.

kapirājacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of a monkey king; royal monkey's way of behaving
kapirājacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound (karmadhāraya) where 'kapi' (monkey) modifies 'rāja' (king), and the whole 'kapirāja' (monkey king) governs 'cariyā' (conduct), indicating the behavior or way of life associated with a monkey king, possibly alluding to a fable or metaphorical context.

darīsaye.meaning_2: lying in a cleft; existing in a cavern
darīsaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'nadīkūle darīsaye', the locative form darīsaye describes the location as 'in a cleft on the riverbank', where 'darī' provides the sense of a natural fissure or cavern, and 'saya' indicates position or existence within it.
darīsaye.translation_1: in a cleft on the riverbank,

labhāmahaṃ.meaning_1: we get; we receive; we obtain
labhāmahaṃ.meaning_2: we could not get; we were unable to obtain (in negative context: na labhāmahaṃ)
labhāmahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'gamanaṃ na labhāmahaṃ', the form labhāmahaṃ is the 1st person plural present indicative of labhati, negated by 'na' to express inability. The enclitic 'ahaṃ' (I) is attached, but the verb form is plural, suggesting 'we' in this context, possibly indicating a collective or inclusive sense. The English translation 'I could not get across' reflects a singular interpretation, but grammatically it is 'we'. The meaning 'get across' aligns with the third sense of labhati: getting through or making understood.

yamhokāse.meaning_2: in whatever space; in whichever place; where
yamhokāse.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form yamhokāse is a locative singular compound of the relative pronoun yamhā (ablative of ya, 'from which') and okāsa ('space, place'), functioning as a locative to mean 'in that space/place from which'. In the sentence 'yamhokāse ahaṃ ṭhatvā', it indicates the location where the speaker stood or was positioned, translated as 'where I used to land' in the context of arrival or positioning.

patāmahaṃ.construction: pata + ti > patā + mi > patāma + haṃ
patāmahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form patāmahaṃ results from sandhi resolution of orā pāraṃ patāmahaṃ, where patāma (1st sg pres of patati, 'I jump/fall') combines with ahaṃ ('I'). In the context of jumping from the near shore (orā) to the far shore (pāraṃ), it conveys the action of leaping across, metaphorically used in Pāli for crossing saṃsāra.
patāmahaṃ.translation_1: when jumping from the near shore to the far,

tatthacchi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form tatthacchi combines the adverb 'tattha' (there) with the aorist 'acchi' from √ās (to sit), functioning as a locative adverbial expression indicating position 'there sitting/crouched'. In the context of the sentence, it describes the location of the deadly foe as crouched in that place, aligning with the English translation 'there crouched my deadly foe'.

luddadassano.meaning_2: fierce-looking; having a savage appearance; baleful
luddadassano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes the gharial as having a fierce or savage appearance, contributing to the 'baleful' connotation in the context of the sentence.

ahaṃpemīti.meaning_2: I go thus; I proceed in this way
ahaṃpemīti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ahaṃpemīti appears to be a sandhi combination of the pronoun 'ahaṃ' (I) and the 1st person singular present of apeti (I go away/depart), with the iti (thus) possibly fused or implied in context. It likely expresses 'I go thus' in a narrative or quotative sense, common in Pāli for self-reporting actions.

matthakamakkamma.meaning_2: stepping on the head; treading upon the head
matthakamakkamma.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a compound gerund where matthakam (accusative of matthaka, 'head') functions adverbially with akkamma ('having trodden'), expressing the action of stepping on his head as in the contextual sentence.

parakūle.meaning_1: on the far bank; on the other side
parakūle.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'parakūle patiṭṭhahiṃ', parakūle is the locative singular form of the compound parakūla, meaning 'on the far bank'. The English translation 'I made it to the far bank' indicates successful arrival or establishment on the opposite shore, often metaphorically referring to reaching enlightenment or safety in Buddhist contexts.
parakūle.translation_1: I made it to the far bank.

akāsahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'yathā vācaṃ akāsahaṃ', the form akāsahaṃ is 1st person singular aorist with enclitic -haṃ ('I'), meaning 'I acted' or 'I did', aligning with the English translation 'but acted according to my word'. The related entry for akāsi (3sg) shares the same aorist pattern, adjusted here for 1sg.
akāsahaṃ.translation_1: but acted according to my word.

kapirājacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the neuter accusative singular form of a compound noun meaning 'the conduct of the monkey king,' likely referring to the seventh (sattamaṃ) story or chapter in a collection like the Cariyāpiṭaka or Jātaka tales, where a monkey acts as king.

saccatāpasacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of a truth-ascetic; way of behaving of a hermit devoted to truth
saccatāpasacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'sacca' (truth) modifies 'tāpasa' (ascetic), and the whole qualifies 'cariyā' (conduct), indicating the ascetic lifestyle or practice centered on truth or mindfulness.

saccasavhayo.meaning_2: having the name Truthful; called Truthful
saccasavhayo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound adjective used predicatively in both sentences to describe an ascetic (tāpaso) or monkey king (kapirājā) who is known by the epithet 'Truthful'. The form ends in -o due to masculine nominative singular agreement with the subject.

janamakāsahanti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'janamakāsahanti' appears to be a scribal error or variant for 'janamakāsahan' ti, where 'janamakāsa' is a compound serving as the object of the verb 'hanti' (strikes). In context, it conveys the idea of striking or uniting the people, as per the English translation.

saccatāpasacariyaṃ.meaning_2: truth-ascetic-conduct; the eighth (in a series or enumeration)
saccatāpasacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound in accusative singular neuter, likely referring to 'the conduct of the truth-ascetic' or 'truthful ascetic's conduct' as the eighth item in a list, possibly of ethical or meditative practices. The form saccatāpasacariyaṃ suggests sandhi resolution from *saccatāpasa-cariyaṃ, with āpas from tāpasa.

vaṭṭapotakacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the young animal in the cycle (of rebirths)
vaṭṭapotakacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a descriptive compound referring to the wandering or behavioral state of a young creature trapped in the cycle of existence (saṃsāra), likely in a Vinaya or sutta context discussing rebirth or ethical conduct.

vaṭṭapotako.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'magadhe vaṭṭapotako', the term refers to a baby quail located in the region of Magadha. Vaṭṭa here denotes the quail (from vaṭṭa as a bird, though not listed in provided entries, common in Pāḷi), and potako is the diminutive indicating youth.

mukhatuṇḍakenāharitvā.meaning_2: with (food) brought in the front of the beak; having fetched with the beak
mukhatuṇḍakenāharitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This sandhi compound functions adverbially, describing the manner in which food was carried by a bird, as per the context 'With food she brought in her beak'. The instrumental case indicates the means (beak), and the absolutive shows prior action.
mukhatuṇḍakenāharitvā.translation_1: With food she brought in her beak

mukhatuṇḍenāharitvā.meaning_2: having fetched with the beak; having carried here with the beak
mukhatuṇḍenāharitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This sandhi form combines the instrumental singular 'mukhatuṇḍena' (with the beak) and the absolutive 'āharitvā' (having brought), indicating an action performed using the beak, likely in a context involving birds or animals.

posayatī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form posayati appears to be a variant or scribal adjustment of posati, with the long ā in the stem reflecting a possible influence from Sanskrit puṣyati. In the sentence 'mātā posayatī mamaṃ', it denotes the mother's act of nurturing or caring for the speaker, aligning with the English translation 'my mother nurtured me'.

gimhasamaye.meaning_2: in the hot season; during the summer
gimhasamaye.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound gimhasamaye is the locative singular form used in the sentence to indicate the time period 'in the hot season', aligning with the English translation. It combines 'gimha' (heat, summer) with 'samaya' (time, season) to specify the summer period.
gimhasamaye.translation_1: One year, in the hot season,

itievaṃ.meaning_2: thus; in this manner; so; like this
itievaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form 'itievaṃ' is a sandhi combination of 'iti' ('thus') and 'evaṃ' ('thus, so'), common in Pāḷi to link statements emphatically. Without provided sentences, the usage is assumed as adverbial, often concluding or emphasizing a narrative or doctrinal point in texts like the Tipiṭaka.

mamamupāgami.meaning_2: approached me; came closer to me
mamamupāgami.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The word is a combination of the dative pronoun 'mamaṃ' (to me) and the aorist verb 'upāgami' (approached), functioning as a single unit meaning 'approached me' or 'came closer to me' in the context of the sentence 'aggi mamamupāgami', where 'aggi' (fire) is the subject.

aggivegabhayātītā.meaning_2: gone beyond the fear of the fierce fire; fearless regarding the impulse of the fire
aggivegabhayātītā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a state of being transcended beyond the terror caused by the rapid or forceful spread of fire, as reflected in the sentence where it conveys being alarmed and terrified at the fierce fire.
aggivegabhayātītā.translation_1: Alarmed and terrified at the fierce fire,

parimocayuṃ.meaning_2: to save; to release; to free oneself
parimocayuṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'attānaṃ parimocayuṃ' indicates the act of saving or freeing themselves, with 'attānaṃ' as the accusative object referring to 'themselves'.

agatiko.meaning_2: unable to leave; without a way out; without destination
agatiko.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'sohaṃ agatiko tattha' meaning 'When unable to leave, there', agatiko describes a state of being trapped or without possibility of departure, akin to having no path or destination out, possibly alluding to the inaccessibility of Nibbāna or a similar concept.

sīlaguṇo.meaning_2: the quality of virtue; the virtuous characteristic
sīlaguṇo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'atthi loke sīlaguṇo', the word functions as the subject of 'atthi', denoting the existence of moral virtue or ethical quality in the world, emphasizing its presence as a positive attribute.
sīlaguṇo.translation_1: There is the quality of virtue in the world,

soceyyanuddayā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form soceyyanuddayā is the nominative singular of a tatpuruṣa compound combining soceyya (purity, from suci) and anuddayā (compassion). In the context of the sentence 'saccaṃ soceyyanuddayā', it functions as a series of three nominative singular terms—truth (saccaṃ), purity (soceyya), and mercy (anuddayā)—likely enumerating qualities or virtues, with the compound serving as a juxtaposed or loosely compounded expression for the latter two.

saccakiriyamuttamaṃ.meaning_2: supreme declaration of truth; supreme truth-act
saccakiriyamuttamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is the neuter accusative singular of the compound adjective 'saccakiriyuttama', used here as a nominal phrase meaning 'a supreme declaration of truth' in the context of a solemn vow or oath invoking truth, as translated in the English sentence.

āvejjetvā.meaning_2: having inspired; having infused; having permeated
āvejjetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, āvejjetvā describes the act of being inspired or permeated by the power of Dhamma, leading to the subsequent effect or state.
āvejjetvā.translation_1: Inspired by the power of Dhamma,

dhammabalaṃ.meaning_2: power of Dhamma; strength from the teaching
dhammabalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, dhammabalaṃ refers to the empowering force or inspiration derived from the Dhamma (Buddhist teachings), as indicated by the English translation 'Inspired by the power of Dhamma'.
dhammabalaṃ.translation_1: Inspired by the power of Dhamma,

saccabalamavassāya.meaning_2: relying on the power of truth
saccabalamavassāya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a locative singular form of a compound noun, used in the context of invoking or depending on the irresistible force inherent in truth, often in protective formulas or vows in Pāḷi literature.
saccabalamavassāya.translation_1: relying on the power of truth,

saccakiriyamakāsahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form saccakiriyamakāsi is a compound verb where the object saccakiriyā (truth-act, solemn declaration) is incorporated before the aorist akāsi of karoti; in context, it expresses the first-person act of uttering a vow or truth-declaration, often with implied efficacy in Pāḷi narratives.
saccakiriyamakāsahaṃ.translation_1: I made a declaration of truth.

sahasacce.meaning_2: declares this truth; proclaims; utters; announces
sahasacce.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'sahacce kate mayhaṃ' means 'when this truth was declared by me' or 'as I declared this truth', where 'sahacce' is the locative singular of the past participle 'sahacca' (declared together/proclaimed), and the entire phrase functions adverbially to indicate the occasion of the declaration.

mahāpajjalito.meaning_2: greatly blazing; greatly burning; with great flames
mahāpajjalito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'mahāpajjalito sikhī', the masculine nominative singular form describes the flames (sikhī) as greatly blazing or having a great crest of fire, aligning with the English translation 'the great crested flames'.

soḷasakarīsāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'soḷasakarīsāni' refers to a distance of sixteen leagues, where 'karīsa' denotes a traditional Indian land measure (approximately an acre), often used in ancient texts to express linear distances like yojanas or leagues.

vaṭṭapotakacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of a young animal in the cycle of existence; ninth (topic)
vaṭṭapotakacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The term refers to the ninth section or topic, likely discussing the behavior or mode of life of young creatures caught in saṃsāra (vaṭṭa), as indicated by the numbering in the sentence.

maccharājacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the king of fish; royal fish behavior
maccharājacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound 'maccharājacariyā' is a descriptive tatpuruṣa, likely referring to the conduct or way of life associated with the 'fish king' (maccha-rāja), possibly metaphorical for a chief or leader in a piscatorial context, or literal in a narrative involving fish. The absence of context sentences limits precise usage, but it aligns with Pāli compounds in ethical or behavioral descriptions.

maccharājā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'maccharājā' refers to a king or ruler among fish, as in 'a fish king in a great lake'. The second sentence likely parallels this usage, with 'vaṭṭako' possibly meaning 'quail' in a proverbial or metaphorical sense.
maccharājā.translation_1: a fish king in a great lake,

sūriyasantāpe.meaning_2: in the heat of the sun
sūriyasantāpe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where sūriya (sun) qualifies santāpa (heat), used here in the locative case to denote 'in the heat of the sun', matching the contextual translation.
sūriyasantāpe.translation_1: in the heat of the sun

kulalasenakā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form kulalasenakā is a feminine nominative singular of a compound noun listing types of birds, matching the English translation as a collective reference to herons, hawks, and falcons. It appears to blend kulala (bird of prey) with senakā (feminine of senaka, hawk), possibly as a dvanda compound or poetic enumeration.

vicintayitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vicintayitvā dhammatthaṃ' indicates the action of having thoughtfully considered or reflected upon the value or essence of the Dhamma, setting the stage for subsequent actions or statements.
vicintayitvā.translation_1: Considering the value of the Dhamma,

dhammatthaṃ.meaning_2: value of the Dhamma; benefit of the teaching; purpose of the doctrine
dhammatthaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, 'dhammatthaṃ' is the accusative singular of the compound 'dhammattha', functioning as the object of 'vicintayitvā'. It refers to the beneficial value or purpose of the Dhamma (Buddhist teachings), aligning with 'attha' meanings of benefit and purpose in relation to 'dhamma' as doctrine.
dhammatthaṃ.translation_1: Considering the value of the Dhamma,

vicintayaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context 'paramatthaṃ vicintayaṃ', it functions as a present participle describing the action of considering or reflecting upon the ultimate goal (paramatthaṃ), likely in an ablative or locative sense indicating the manner or object of contemplation.

dhuvasassataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'dhuvasassataṃ' describes something that would endure forever in the world, combining the notions of stability and eternity, often applied to concepts like Nibbāna.
dhuvasassataṃ.translation_1: that would last eternally in the world.

abhitthanaya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'abhitthanaya' is an instrumental singular form used as an adverbial phrase with 'pajjunna', meaning 'by thundering' or 'with thunder', exhorting the storm god Pajjuna to thunder forth.

sahakate.meaning_1: done together; performed jointly; accomplished in common
sahakate.meaning_2: something done together; joint action; lit. done with
sahakate.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sahakate is the locative singular of the neuter past participle sahakata, derived from saha (with, together) + kata (done, from √kar). It indicates an action performed in conjunction with others, often in a communal or shared context in Pāḷi texts.

saccavare.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'saccavare' is the locative singular form used adverbially to indicate the circumstance under which the truth was declared, emphasizing its excellence.
saccavare.translation_1: As this excellent truth was declared,

abhigajjiya.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'pajjunno abhigajjiya' describes Pajjuna, the rain god, performing an action of thundering, with the absolutive indicating attendant circumstance to the main verb 'thundered forth'.

saccavaraṃ.meaning_2: supreme truth; supreme effort; supreme exertion
saccavaraṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given context, 'evarūpaṃ saccavaraṃ' is translated as 'having made such supreme effort,' suggesting 'saccavaraṃ' functions adverbially to indicate a supreme or utmost effort, likely in the sense of striving for truth or in a spiritual pursuit, with 'varaṃ' providing the superlative nuance of excellence or superiority.

vīriyamuttamaṃ.meaning_2: supreme effort; highest energy; utmost determination
vīriyamuttamaṃ.construction: vīriy + a + m uttam + a + ṃ
vīriyamuttamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence 'katvā vīriyamuttamaṃ', the accusative form functions as the object of 'katvā' (having done), indicating the performance of supreme effort, aligning with the English translation 'for this excellent truth' where 'excellent' corresponds to the superlative sense of 'uttamaṃ' applied to 'vīriya'.

saccatejabalassito.meaning_2: relying on the force of the power of truth
saccatejabalassito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where saccateja functions as the object of balassa (genitive 'of the power'), and -ito is the instrumental singular of assita, indicating reliance or dependence. In context, it describes something supported by the inherent power or force derived from truth, often in a soteriological or magical sense in Buddhist texts.
saccatejabalassito.translation_1: relying on the force of the power of truth.

maccharājacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of the king of stinginess; the tenth (chapter or section)
maccharājacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the accusative singular form of a compound noun used as the title of the tenth section in the Cariyāpiṭaka, describing the conduct exemplifying the perfection of generosity through overcoming stinginess.

kaṇhadīpāyanacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of the way of the dark lamp
kaṇhadīpāyanacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound interpreting as 'cariyā (conduct) of āyana (way) of dīpā (lamp, with dīpa in gen. sg.) of kaṇha (dark)'. The meaning 'dark lamp' may refer metaphorically to a misleading or false light, possibly in a doctrinal context like a wrong path or sūtra, with cariyā indicating the practice or behavior associated with it.

kaṇhadīpāyano.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a compound name where 'kaṇha' means 'dark' and 'dīpāyana' likely derives from 'dīpa' (light) with 'āyana' indicating a path or approach, together forming 'Dark Light' as an epithet for the seer (isi) in the given context.

paropaññāsavassāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This accusative plural form indicates duration exceeding fifty years, as in the context of a long period of time.

anabhiratocariṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is an accusative singular aorist with anabhirata as an adverbial modifier, indicating the manner of living as dissatisfied, aligning with the English translation 'I lived dissatisfied'.

anabhiratimanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form anabhiratimanaṃ is the neuter accusative singular of the compound anabhiratimana, used possessively to indicate the speaker's own dissatisfaction or discontent, as reflected in the contextual sentence.

pubbakammasamāyutto.meaning_2: bound to a deed in a past life; connected with a previous action
pubbakammasamāyutto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'pubbakamma' (deed from a past existence) is qualified by 'samāyutta' (connected with, yoked to). The overall sense in context refers to a being whose current state or rebirth is determined by the binding effect of a past action, as in karmic retribution.
pubbakammasamāyutto.translation_1: Bound to a deed in a past life,

sūlamāropanaṃ.meaning_2: impaling on a stake; act of being raised onto a spike; punishment of impalement
sūlamāropanaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, sūlamāropanaṃ refers to the punitive act of being impaled on a stake, likely as a form of execution or torture, with labhi indicating the subject received this fate.
sūlamāropanaṃ.translation_1: he got impaled on a stake.

upaṭṭhahitvāna.meaning_2: having nursed; having attended on; having cared for; having served
upaṭṭhahitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, the absolutive form upaṭṭhahitvāna indicates the action of nursing or attending to someone, completed prior to the main action, aligning with the English translation 'I nursed him'.

ārogyamanupāpayiṃ.meaning_2: and brought him back to health
ārogyamanupāpayiṃ.construction: ā + √ruh > rūh + *a + *ya > rūḍha; rūḍha + *a + *ya > ropayati; ā + ropayati > āropeti > āropayī
ārogyamanupāpayiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ārogyamanupāpayiṃ appears to be a scribal error or variant for ārogyamanupāropayī, where āropayī causatively means 'brought back' or 'restored', fitting the context of restoring to health (ārogya). The prefix anu indicates 'back' or 'again', and the accusative ārogyaṃ is the object, meaning 'restored to health'. The -ṃ ending is likely a manuscript variant for -ṃ (acc. sg. nt), but the verb is 1st sg. aorist.
ārogyamanupāpayiṃ.translation_1: and brought him back to health.

āpucchitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence, it functions as an absolutive indicating the action prior to the main verb 'āgañchiṃ' (I returned), expressing that the returning occurred after asking leave.

sakamassamaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sakamassamaṃ is the accusative singular of the tatpuruṣa compound sakassama, meaning 'one's own hermitage', used here to refer to the speaker's personal monastery or retreat.

pāhunāgataṃ.meaning_2: arrived as a guest; guest; visitor
pāhunāgataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'āgañchuṃ pāhunāgataṃ', the word functions as a neuter noun in accusative singular, serving as the object of 'āgañchuṃ' (come), translated as 'as my guests'. The compound combines 'pāhunā' (as guest, instrumental) with 'āgataṃ' (arrived), indicating those who have come in the capacity of guests.

sakamassame.meaning_2: one's own hermitage; my own monastery
sakamassame.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form sakamassame is the locative singular of the compound sakaṃ assamaṃ, used here to indicate the location 'in my own hermitage' as per the sentence context.

vaṭṭamanukkhipaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'dārako vaṭṭamanukkhipaṃ', the word is the direct object of the verb, referring to a ball that the boy threw. 'Vaṭṭa' means 'round' or 'circle', 'manu' relates to mind but here likely a connective or error in parsing, and 'ukkhipaṃ' from ukkhipati means 'thrown up', indicating the action of throwing. The compound describes the ball as something thrown.

āsīvisamakopayi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form āsīvisamakopayi is a present participle of a denominative verb derived from āsīvisa, meaning 'causing to become angry' or 'angering', used here in the context of provoking or enraging a viper, as translated 'angered a viper'.

vaṭṭagataṃ.meaning_2: gone to the cycle; entered into rebirth; gone into the round of existence
vaṭṭagataṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'vaṭṭagataṃ maggaṃ' likely means 'the path that has gone into the cycle' or 'the path leading to rebirth,' contrasting with paths leading to liberation. The English translation 'looking which way' appears incomplete or mismatched, possibly indicating a directional sense of the path within samsara.
vaṭṭagataṃ.translation_1: Then the boy, looking which way

visabalassito.meaning_2: relying on potent poison; dependent on the strength of venom
visabalassito.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound visa-bala- means 'the strength/power of poison', referring to the potent venom of the snake. The past participle assita conveys reliance or dependence, fitting the context of the snake depending on its poison for potency.
visabalassito.translation_1: the snake, relying on its potent poison,

paramakopena.meaning_2: with highest anger; with extreme rage
paramakopena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular form used adverbially to indicate the manner of being enraged, as in 'completely enraged'.

sahadaṭṭho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental sense 'by' conveyed through the preposition saha compounded with the past participle daṭṭho, indicating the agent or means of the biting action in the context of being bitten by a viper.

vāhasi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'mama vāhasi taṃ dukkhaṃ', the verb expresses that the speaker bears or experiences the pain as their own, conveying a sense of empathetic or vicarious suffering.
vāhasi.translation_1: the pain became as if mine.

assāsayitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'assāsayitvāna' functions as an absolutive form indicating the action of comforting the parents (tyāhaṃ assāsayitvāna), prior to the main action.

sokasallite.meaning_2: arrow of sorrow; dart of grief
sokasallite.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, 'sokasallite' is the locative singular of the compound 'sokasallita', meaning 'in the arrow of sorrow' or 'pierced by sorrow'. It parallels 'dukkhite' (in suffering), indicating a state of being afflicted by sorrow as part of suffering.

sattāhamevāhaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This sandhi form combines the adverb 'sattāhameva' ('for just seven days') with the pronoun 'ahaṃ' ('I'), used in the context of expressing a short duration of faith or conviction lasting exactly seven days.
sattāhamevāhaṃ.translation_1: ‘For just seven days with a mind of faith

mamedaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'athāparaṃ yaṃ caritaṃ mamedaṃ', mamedaṃ functions as a fused genitive-accusative pronoun meaning 'my life' or 'this life of mine', referring to the speaker's life since then, as translated in English.

paññāsasamādhikāni.meaning_2: more than fifty; fifty or more
paññāsasamādhikāni.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'vassāni paññāsasamādhikāni', the compound functions as a neuter plural adjective modifying 'vassāni' (years), indicating a duration exceeding fifty years, translated as 'for fifty years or more'.

visavegena.meaning_2: with poison and trembling; with toxin and urgency
visavegena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental singular of the tatpuruṣa compound visavega, used adverbially to describe the state of the boy who is struck and trembling due to the effects of poison, combining the notions of poison and its urgent, forceful impact.

abujjhitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'abujjhitvāna vuṭṭhāsi', the absolutive form indicates the action of awakening preceding the main verb 'got up', describing the sequence of events.

kaṇhadīpāyanacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of the dark-lamp way; behavior of the path illuminated by darkness
kaṇhadīpāyanacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the eleventh in a series (ekādasamaṃ), likely referring to a specific chapter or section titled 'Conduct of the Dark Lamp Way' in a Pāli text such as the Cariyāpiṭaka or a similar work on bodhisatta conduct. The compound suggests a metaphorical path (dīpāyana) associated with darkness (kaṇha), possibly indicating an unconventional or challenging aspect of spiritual practice.

sutasomacariyā.meaning_2: good conduct of the moon (son); conduct of the lunar son; behavior of the moon (as son)
sutasomacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a tatpuruṣa compound where 'suta' (son) modifies 'soma' (moon), and the resulting 'sutasoma' (lunar son or son of the moon) modifies 'cariyā' (conduct). Likely refers to the virtuous behavior or story associated with the moon deity as a son figure in Buddhist or mythological context.

sutasomo.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Proper name of a king or lord, interpreted as 'having a good son' or 'son of Soma', used in vocative case as direct address in the sentence. The English translation treats it as a title equivalent to 'Lord of the Earth'.

āvuṇitvā.meaning_2: having strung up; having hung up by
āvuṇitvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, āvuṇitvā describes the action of having strung up or hung someone by their hands, as in tying or suspending by the arms or wrists.
āvuṇitvā.translation_1: he strung up by their hands .

karattale.meaning_2: by the palms of the hands; by the hands
karattale.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'karattale' refers to being suspended by the palms or hands, as in tying the hands above the head for punishment or execution.
karattale.translation_1: he strung up by their hands .

pamilāpetvā.meaning_2: having drained; having sucked out; having emptied
pamilāpetvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'pamilāpetvā' describes the action of completely draining or sucking out the blood of the beings referred to by 'etesaṃ', likely in a metaphorical or ritual sense, as an absolutive indicating a prior action.

upanayī.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'yaññatthe upanayī mamaṃ', upanayī is the subject referring to the person who brought the speaker ('me') for the purpose of sacrifice (yañña). It functions as an agent noun indicating the one who performed the action of bringing.

yathāmati.meaning_2: as one thinks; according to one's thought; as you think
yathāmati.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'yathāmati te kāhāmi', it functions adverbially to mean 'as you think' or 'according to your intention', indicating the manner of action corresponding to the addressee's thought or wish.
yathāmati.translation_1: I shall act as you think,

punehisi.meaning_2: you will return; you will come again
punehisi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'yadi me tvaṃ punehisi' ('so long as you will return'), the word punehisi expresses a future conditional action of returning, likely to the speaker ('me'), emphasizing the condition for the ongoing situation.
punehisi.translation_1: so long as you will return.’

paṭissuṇitvāna.meaning_2: having promised; having undertaken; having consented
paṭissuṇitvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'tassa paṭissuṇitvāna', the absolutive form indicates an action completed prior to the main verb, here translating to 'having promised him that I...', showing the act of promising as antecedent to the subsequent narrative.

paṇhe.meaning_2: at dawn; in the early morning
paṇhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'paṇhe āgamanaṃ mama', paṇhe is the locative singular form indicating time/place, meaning 'at dawn'. The English translation 'would return at dawn' shows its contextual use as the time of return.

niyyādayiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'rajjaṃ niyyādayiṃ tadā', the aorist form niyyādayiṃ indicates the act of renouncing the kingdom, paralleling the English 'and then renounced kingship'. The verb conveys the sense of relinquishing royal authority.

jinasevitaṃ.meaning_2: fostered by former Victors; practised by previous Conquerors
jinasevitaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the compound pubbakaṃ jinasevitaṃ, 'jinasevitaṃ' functions as the object, describing a path or practice that was associated with or fostered by previous Victors (pubba-jina), emphasizing continuity in Buddhist tradition.

saccavācānurakkhanto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context, it describes the act of safeguarding one's commitment to truthful speech, emphasizing ethical protection of veracity.

cajitumupāgamiṃ.grammar: aor of upāgacchati, inf obj cajituṃ
cajitumupāgamiṃ.meaning_2: went to give up (my life); approached (the act of) abandoning (life)
cajitumupāgamiṃ.construction: upa + ā + √gam + iṃ, obj inf √caj + tuṃ
cajitumupāgamiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is 1st person singular aorist with infinitive object 'cajituṃ' (to give up/abandon) from √caj, indicating purposeful approach to an action; in context, it means 'I went to give up my life' as per the provided sentence.
cajitumupāgamiṃ.translation_1: I went to give up my life.

sutasomacariyaṃ.meaning_2: good conduct of the heard; proper behavior regarding the teachings
sutasomacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of 'sutasomacariyaṃ dvādasamaṃ', this compound likely refers to the twelfth item or chapter, denoting the good or proper conduct associated with the heard teachings (suta, i.e., the Dhamma or scriptures), where 'soma' functions as an intensifying prefix meaning 'good' or 'proper'. The form is accusative singular, possibly as the object in a larger phrase.

suvaṇṇasāmacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound adjective 'suvaṇṇasāma-' (golden-brown) qualifying 'cariyā' (conduct), likely denoting a life or conduct characterized by golden-brown (possibly a metaphorical or specific doctrinal term); exact contextual meaning unclear without sentences.

mettāyamupanāmayiṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This appears to be a sandhi compound of two aorist forms, possibly functioning as a coordinated verbal expression in narrative style, with the -ṃ indicating accusative or some inflectional ending adapted to the compound.

pasadamigavarāhehi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Instrumental plural form of a tatpuruṣa compound denoting spotted deer and wild boar, used in context to refer to these animals collectively.

mettābalenupatthaddho.meaning_2: sustained by the power of loving-kindness; supported by the strength of benevolence
mettābalenupatthaddho.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a bahubbīhi compound where the instrumental form mettābalena (power of mettā) qualifies the past participle upatthaddho (supported), describing someone who is upheld or sustained by the strength of mettā, as reflected in the English translation 'Sustained by the power of love'.
mettābalenupatthaddho.translation_1: Sustained by the power of love

suvaṇṇasāmacariyaṃ.meaning_2: the thirteenth conduct; the thirteenth way of behaving
suvaṇṇasāmacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is a descriptive compound where suvaṇṇa (golden) modifies sāma (brown, possibly referring to a person or type), and cariya (conduct) is the head, with the ordinal terasamaṃ (thirteenth) indicating its position in a sequence of such conducts, likely in a narrative or doctrinal list.

ekarājacariyā.meaning_2: conduct of a single king; royal solitary conduct
ekarājacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Compound adjective used as feminine noun in instrumental singular, likely describing a mode of conduct associated with a single or solitary kingly figure, possibly in a narrative or doctrinal context.

ekarājāti.meaning_2: in one reign; during one sovereignty
ekarājāti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form ekarājāti is an adverbial locative derived from the tatpuruṣa compound ekarājā (eka + rāja), indicating the time or period of 'one king' or 'one reign'. In the sentence 'ekarājāti vissuto', it modifies the past participle vissuto ('renowned' or 'famous'), describing the Buddha as renowned in or during one reign, emphasizing his singular sovereignty or the unified period under his rule.

saṅgahāmi.meaning_2: I take up; I bind; I attach myself
saṅgahāmi.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form saṅgahāmi is the 1st person singular present indicative of saṅgahati, a causative verb derived from saṅga (attachment) with the causative suffix -āhāya, functioning as a present stem saṅgahā-. It expresses the action of attaching or binding oneself, often in contexts of commitment or adherence.

dabbaseno.meaning_2: by Dabbasena; with the army of Dabbasena
dabbaseno.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the given sentence 'dabbaseno upagantvā', the word is in the instrumental case, indicating agency in the attack. It functions as an instrumental compound where 'dabba' refers to the monk Dabbasena (from dabba 1.2), and 'sena' means 'army' (from sena 2.1), thus 'with the army of Dabbasena' or 'by Dabbasena's forces', aligning with the English translation 'Dabbasena attacked'.

rājūpajīve.meaning_2: royal dependent; one who lives dependent on the king
rājūpajīve.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form rājūpajīve is the locative singular of this masculine compound noun, used in the sentence to refer to royal dependents or retainers residing in the city, as indicated by the context 'The royal dependents in the city'.
rājūpajīve.translation_1: The royal dependents in the city,

sabalaṭṭhe.meaning_2: with the military and the citizens; with soldiers and townsfolk
sabalaṭṭhe.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] This is the locative singular of a dvanda compound sabalaṭṭha-saraṭṭhaka, meaning 'soldiers and citizens', used instrumentally/locatively in context to indicate association 'with the military and the citizens'. The form sabalaṭṭhe results from sandhi where -a from balaṭṭha combines with the following word.
sabalaṭṭhe.translation_1: with the military and the citizens—

amaccamaṇḍalaṃ.meaning_2: circle of ministers; court circle; flourishing kingdom
amaccamaṇḍalaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound combines 'amacca' (minister, royal official) with 'maṇḍala' (circle, sphere, area), referring to the circle or assembly of court ministers, poetically denoting the flourishing kingdom in the given context.
amaccamaṇḍalaṃ.translation_1: The court ministers, the flourishing kingdom,

acchinditvāna.meaning_2: having cut off; having cut down
acchinditvāna.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence 'acchinditvāna gahitaṃ' meaning 'were captured and held', the absolutive form indicates the action of cutting off or capturing that precedes the main verb, likely referring to the act of seizing or apprehending someone or something before holding them.

passahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'piyaṃ puttaṃva passahaṃ', the form passahaṃ is the 1st person singular aorist of √dis ('to see'), meaning 'I saw'. The suffix -haṃ indicates 1st singular, and the context with 'piyaṃ puttaṃva' (even my beloved son) emphasizes seeing the son.
passahaṃ.translation_1: I even saw my beloved son.

ekarājacariyaṃ.meaning_2: conduct of a single king; royal conduct
ekarājacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] Appears as accusative singular in the sentence 'ekarājacariyaṃ cuddasamaṃ', likely meaning 'the conduct of a single king (is) the fourteenth', referring to the fourteenth type of conduct or mode of life in a Buddhist context.

mahālomahaṃsacariyā.meaning_2: great conduct causing goosebumps; venerable behavior that inspires awe or terror
mahālomahaṃsacariyā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound describes a profound or awe-inspiring conduct, where 'lomahaṃsa' evokes a sense of thrilling reverence or fear, as in epic narratives.

upanidhāyahaṃ.meaning_2: resting on; based on; depending on
upanidhāyahaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form upanidhāyahaṃ is a fused adverbial expression combining the locative singular of upanidhā ('comparison; resemblance') with the adverb yahaṃ ('wherever'), used here in the context of 'resting on a skeleton' to indicate a basis or dependency, likely in a metaphorical sense describing a frail or skeletal support.

gāmamaṇḍalā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] A tatpuruṣa compound denoting a circular arrangement or collective area of villages, likely referring to a rural district or grouped hamlets in a circular formation.

upāgantvā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the sentence 'gāmaṇḍalā upāgantvā', the absolutive upāgantvā indicates the action completed before the main verb 'āgamiṃsu' (implied or elided), meaning the village louts approached and then came up.

dassentinappakaṃ.meaning_2: showing a little; exhibiting in a small amount
dassentinappakaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a sandhi compound of the present participle 'dassenti' (showing) and the adjective 'anappakaṃ' (considerable, not small) in accusative neuter singular, agreeing with 'rūpaṃ' (form, appearance). In context, it describes mocking through various small or repeated gestures or appearances, as per the English translation implying diverse ways of mockery.
dassentinappakaṃ.translation_1: and mocked me in all sorts of ways.

upāyanānūpanenti.meaning_2: bring forward many kinds of offerings; present many gifts
upāyanānūpanenti.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is a compound verb incorporating the neuter noun upāyana ('offering, gift') as an adverbial accusative specifying the object, combined with the negated present upaneti ('leads near, brings'). In context, it describes bringing or presenting many kinds of cooked food as offerings.
upāyanānūpanenti.translation_1: and many kinds of cooked food,

saṃviggamānasā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound saṃviggamānasa describes the state of the minds being thrilled and elated, as per the context of beings filled with joy and awe.

tulābhūto.meaning_2: balanced; equanimous; become like a balance
tulābhūto.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'tulābhūto' describes a state of mental equanimity where pleasure and pain are treated with impartiality, like objects on a balanced scale, indicative of meditative or ethical balance in Pāḷi Buddhist texts.
tulābhūto.translation_1: I became balanced towards pleasure and pain,

mahālomahaṃsacariyaṃ.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The form is accusative singular of a compound adjective modifying an unexpressed 'cariyaṃ' or similar, but parsed as the compound itself in accusative. In context, 'pannarasamaṃ' indicates 'the fifteenth', so this is the title of the fifteenth conduct or chapter in a series like the Cariyāpiṭaka, referring to the great conduct or story of the private Buddha Lomahaṃsa.

somanasso.meaning_2: joyful in battle; delighting in war
somanasso.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound somanasso functions as a descriptive epithet for yudhañjayo, indicating a state of mental joy or gladness specifically in the context of battle, likely characterizing a warrior or conqueror who finds delight in combat.

ayogharabhisena.meaning_2: by a physician who is homeless
ayogharabhisena.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound ayogharabhisena is an instrumental singular form used in a context likely involving a homeless physician or healer, combining 'aya' (possibly 'coming' or 'way' in compound sense), 'aghara' (homeless), and 'bhisa' (physician); the exact nuance of 'aya' may be intensifying or specifying the approach or path of the homeless healer.

soṇanando.meaning_2: Soṇa Nando, the monk who is mute; lit. dog-happy
soṇanando.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] In the context of the sentence, 'soṇanando mūgapakkho' refers to the monk Soṇa Nando, who is described as being on the side of muteness or having a mute quality, possibly indicating a literal or metaphorical dumbness.

kapirājā.comment: [openrouter: openrouter/sonoma-dusk-alpha] The compound kapirājā refers to the Monkey King in the context of the Jātaka story, whose name is Saccavhāya, emphasizing truthfulness.
